**Summary:** The speaker discusses the revolutionary idea that giving up material duties for pure devotional service can free one from obligations, and addresses the question of what happens if someone falls down from devotional service.

Under all circumstances, in all times, in all situations. So, spiritual duties are definitely very, very important. So, generally, people who are aware of these material duties and spiritual duties, they try to discharge both of them. Any civilized person will have some sense of responsibility for discharging material duties, and also will be doing some kind of worship of the Supreme, some kind of spiritual duties one will be discharging. But here, Narad Muni is telling something very, very revolutionary, that if somebody is giving up the material duties in order to engage in pure devotional service, as instructed in the Bhagavatam, that when you engage in pure devotional service by surrendering to Krishna, then you have no obligation, no material obligations at all. Then such a person, if such a person performs pure devotional service and becomes completely successful in getting ultimate liberation, then very good. The person is liberated, freed from all material contamination, purified, no more material obligations, and has attained the success in pure devotional service of getting ultimate liberation, going back home, back to Godhead. But what if they fall down after taking to pure devotional service? That happens when somebody is still in an immature stage. bhajan apapvo atha patetato yadi. Then they fall down means they give up devotional, pure devotional service, and they take to material life once again, which they had given up in order to do pure devotional service. Then what about this person's situation? Neither has he gained anything materially by engaging in pure devotional service, nor has that person been successful in doing his pure devotional service. So he is a loser both ways. So Narada Muni is telling, there is no loss for such a person who in an immature stage, after having taken to pure devotional service, gives up pure devotional service and goes back to material way of life. There is no loss at all. There is no loss. Why?

He performed, he gave up his kingdom and went to a holy place, and he was practicing pure devotional service. And then, towards the end of his life, he became attached to a deer, and he died thinking of the deer. So, he took birth, next birth, as a deer. But, because he had done pure devotional service, the Lord was kind enough to give him memory of what he did in his previous life. In the body of a deer, he was able to remember. And in that body of a deer, he was associating with saintly persons and hearing their discourses. He was not interested in eating or sleeping or nothing, even in the body of a deer. He realized his mistake, and he was delivered. Next life, even though he took birth as a demon, in the body of a demon, not as a demon, in the body of a demon, he was delivered, completely delivered. Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Chai Vanarottamam Devim Saraswathim Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Rayet In this session we will be discussing from the 21st verse of the 5th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. Tvam Atmana Atmanam Avehi Amoghadrik Parasya Pumsah Paramatmanah Kalam Ajam Prajatam Jagatashivayatat Mahanubhavabhyudayo Adhiganyatam The meaning of this verse is, your goodness has perfect vision. You yourself can know the supreme personality of Godhead. I am sorry. You yourself can know the Supersoul personality of Godhead because you are present as the plenary portion of the Lord. Although you are birthless, you have appeared on this earth for the well-being of all people. Please therefore describe the transcendental pastimes of the supreme personality of Godhead Shri Krishna more vividly. This is yet another verse spoken by Shri Narada to Vyasadeva. He is instructing Vyasadeva on compiling Bhagavatam. And Bhagavatam is specifically describing, very vividly, supposed to describe very detailed way, the various transcendental pastimes of the supreme personality of Godhead Krishna. Krishna means Krishna and his various transcendental forms of expansion, various incarnations. So all of them are included. So here Vyasadeva is essentially being told that Vyasa is actually the incarnation of the Supreme Lord for the sake of compiling the Vedic literature. So he has perfect vision. He is himself the plenary portion. Plenary portion means the portion of the Supreme Lord who has got the power of the Supreme Lord. So he himself knows the Supersoul personality of Godhead by his perfect vision. And even though he is birthless, Ajam Prajatam, Ajam means he is birthless, Prajatam means he has taken birth for the well-being of all people. Shivaya for the well-being of all people. Therefore, Narada Muni is telling, describe the transcendental pastimes of the Supreme Personality of Godhead Sri Krishna more vividly. In the earlier work of Vyasa Deva, the different Puranas and the Mahabharata, he has described the pastimes of the Supreme Lord, but not as detailed as it will be described by him in the Bhagavatam under the instruction of Narada. Just like the 10th canto of the Srimad Bhagavatam is fully dedicated for describing the pastimes of Krishna very, very, very detailed way. It is the biggest canto in the entire Srimad Bhagavatam. And it is also describing the pastimes of Krishna's birth, then the childhood pastimes in Vrindavan. Then the pastimes of Krishna as youth in the Mathura Dham, then his pastimes as the king of Dwaraka in Dwaraka. All the pastimes are very nicely, vividly, detailed way described in the Bhagavatam 10th canto. And the other cantos are establishing the pastimes of Krishna. Who is this personality of Godhead Krishna? What is his transcendental nature? What is his relationship with this material world, with the spiritual world, with the living beings, with the liberated souls, with the jnanis, tapasvis, karmis, yogis, devotees, everybody? All that is very scientifically described in connection with his pastimes. This is the special thing. Everything is connected with Krishna's pastimes.

Impersonalists actually have no proper understanding of Vedanta philosophy, because they start with an assumption, even though unjustified, that ultimately, the Absolute Truth is impersonal. But, actually, the Absolute Truth has got three features. Impersonal feature is just one of the preliminary understanding of the Absolute Truth. There are two other features, the Paramatma feature and the Bhagavan feature. So, this Paramatma feature and the Bhagavan feature are completely mis-doubted by the impersonalists. Therefore, their understanding of Vedanta, is not complete. It is imperfect. It is incomplete, and it is misleading also, that ultimately, the Absolute Truth is impersonal. No. The Absolute Truth is the personality of Godhead. Therefore, Vedantavadis, refers to the pure devotees of the Supreme Lord, who have full understanding of all the three features of the Absolute Truth. Such Vedantavadis are also called as Bhaktivedantas. They are impartial in distributing the transcendental knowledge of devotional service. To them, nobody is enemy, nobody is friend. ### fruitive work, emperic philosophy, transcendental realization, material benefits
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/3jkSsUpVw-4?t=356
**Verse References:** —

**Key Quote:** "Any transaction either in the field of fruity work or in emperic philosophy, which is not ultimately aimed at transcendental realization of the Supreme Lord is considered to be useless."
**Summary:** The speaker explains that activities aimed at material gain or self-realization are useless if they don't lead to transcendental realization of the Supreme Lord.

Any Vedic mantra begins with Om and it has got these words in the mantra in order to invoke the presence of the Lord through such chanting. The purport is, now what is the meaning of this whole thing that has been described in this particular verse? Any transaction either in the field of fruity work or in emperic philosophy, which is not ultimately aimed at transcendental realization of the Supreme Lord is considered to be useless. In the Vedas, there are so many recommendations in terms of doing fruity work. What is fruity work? Any work done which will give a result of some material benefit. And emperic philosophy is knowledge which will lead to realization of the Self. So whether in the field of karma or jnana, which is something which is not aimed at transcendental realization of the Supreme Lord, ultimately the goal should always be in every activity, even what is recommended in the scriptures or otherwise. The aim should be transcendental realization of the Supreme Lord. Only that is having a permanent benefit for the soul. Otherwise, any sort of material gain, it is simply a temporary benefit. It is not going to save us ultimately when we have to face the cataclysms of material nature, when we have to face death, or when we have to face pralaya, when we have to face some natural calamities, or when we have to face material miseries which are forced upon us, then all the material benefits are useless.

They may give some temporary satisfaction, some temporary happiness, some temporary effects may be there, but they will not be eternally lasting. Now, as far as the four classes of bad men are concerned, they are also described in the Bhagavad Gita. The first category of bad men that are described, those who are simply addicted to the mode of progressive fruity work. Fruity work means they have to do some work in which they get some results for their material enjoyment, material pleasure, material gain. That is called fruity work. So, there are people who are addicted to progressive fruity work and they keep on doing this, and as a result, they are subjected to the accompanying miseries. Nothing in this material world, any material work done, is always accompanied by miseries. You cannot say, I will do something and I want only pleasure. No, not possible. Always there is pleasure and pain, or enjoyment and suffering. Sukha and dukkha are two sides of the same coin. Two sides of the same coin, material activity, fructive activity. So, this is the first class of bad men. The second class of bad men are those who are simply addicted to vicious work, sinful activities. For what? For sense gratification, for sense satisfaction. And naturally they suffer the consequences because they are outright engaging in sinful activity. They have to suffer. Sooner or later, they have to suffer. And the third class of bad men are those who are materially advanced in knowledge, but they suffer. In spite of being advanced in knowledge, they suffer because they do not have the sense to acknowledge the authority of the Almighty Supreme Lord. So, what happens? The effect of their knowledge is stolen away by the illusory energy: Māyayā pahṛtaṁ jñānam. ### cyclical creation, mundane wranglers, spiritual inquiry
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/i1qa4vYcCXw?t=309
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers, General public
**Key Quote:** "The mundane wranglers waste time and energy with archeological excavations without searching into the vital necessities of life."
**Summary:** The speaker discusses Srila Prabhupada's commentary on the cyclical nature of creation and criticizes 'mundane wranglers' who focus on material discoveries rather than spiritual inquiry.

So very interesting purport by Srila Prabhupada, a very pertinent observation is made by Srila Prabhupada. Kindly note this. Prabhupada says in the purport, "Man's activities in agriculture, mining, farming, industries, gardening etc. were all on the same scale as they are now." Sometimes we think when we read so-called history that there was a primitive civilization of man was very primitive condition caveman and then gradually evolved to become the present civilized society but that is not the fact. Man's activities in all these fields agriculture mining farming industries gardening etc. were on the same scale as they are now even previous to the present creation and the same activities will remain as they are even in the next creation cyclically this is going on creation maintenance destruction again creation maintenance destruction in a day of Brahma in a day of Brahma of course there are changes that happen even within one day of Brahma but at the beginning of the day of Brahma there is creation and the end of day of Brahma there is destruction so in between there is there are changes taking place with essentially man's activities at least on the earth are similar to what was there in a previous creation. So, Srila Prabhupada says, after many hundreds of millions of years, one creation is started by the law of nature and the history of the universe repeats itself practically in the same way. It is out of necessity that human beings have to do cultivation of the field and then there are forests which give certain produce without any human endeavor by the arrangement of the Supreme Lord through the nature, mother nature and then there are mines which has got deposits of different minerals, different metals, that mining activity was always there even in the past and it is there now and will be there in the future also. So, the history of the universe repeats itself practically in the same way. As far as major activities are concerned among the different classes of people on different planets, it repeats itself. Now, here is the important observation that Srila Prabhupada is making. The mundane wranglers waste time and energy. They waste time with archeological excavations without searching into the vital necessities of life. So, mundane wranglers. Mundane means they are only concerned with matter and material things and material existence. They are not have understanding of something beyond matter. They do not know who they are. They do not know their spirit. They don't know there is a spiritual dimension to existence in every human being, every living being actually, particularly in a human being. And there is a spiritual world beyond this material world, which is eternal. Of this, there are people who have no knowledge, no idea, no trace of any understanding. Totally zero when it comes to spiritual understanding. So they are called mundane wranglers.

They are simply busy with material things. And they are fascinated if they discover something by excavation. Some ancient civilization, they had beautiful buildings. They had a... They had, you know, gold coins. They had a system of mining and purifying. Metallurgy was very advanced even thousands of years back. When they discover all this through excavations, then they waste so much time into rebuilding so-called history. But... What they... Are losing out is the valuable human life, the time we can spend in this human form of life into searching out the vital necessity of this human form of life. What is that? Inquiry into the absolute truth. In just three words in Vedanta Sutra, the whole thing is summarized: Athato Brahma Jijnasa. Vital necessity of life. Inquire into what is spirit. What is Brahman or who is God. Or who you are. Inquire into this. Without making this inquiry, human life is completely wasted. All the developed intelligence, the ability to ask fundamental questions and try to get meaningful answers, this opportunity is lost. It's a greatest loss for a human being. In the evolution of the consciousness through different species of life in this material world, the human form of life is the most evolved, developed state of consciousness. So, therefore, it is very well known human being is a rational animal, can think, can contemplate, can inquire, can learn, can teach, can do so many things with this developed intelligence, developed consciousness. ### detachment, renunciation, spiritual life
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/J643v1bHGEQ?t=64
**Verse References:** SB 1.6.12
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Somebody serious about spiritual life will never be attracted to any place which is meant for satisfying the senses."
**Summary:** Narada Muni's travels are described, emphasizing his detachment from material attractions and focus on spiritual pursuits.

In this session, we will be discussing from the twelfth verse of the sixth chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. Chitradhatu Vichitradrin Ibha Bhagna Bhujadruman Jalashayan Shivajalan Nalini Surasevitaha Chitrasvanai Patrarathair Vibhrahmad Bhramara Shriyaha. The meaning of this verse is: I pass through hills and mountains full of reservoirs of various minerals like gold, silver, and copper, and through tracts of land with reservoirs of water filled with beautiful lotus flowers fit for the denizens of heaven, decorated with bewildered bees and singing birds. Naradamuni is describing his travel. He passed through different kinds of places, and as it will be explained in the next verse, it is the duty of a sanyasi, a renunciant, or one dedicated to spiritual life, to actually travel through different tracts of land which are all the creation of the supreme lord in this material world, and none of such places have any attraction for a serious spiritualist like Narada. There is no attraction. He is passing through reservoirs of gold, silver, copper, but he has no attraction for them, neither is he attracted to a beautiful place filled with clear water and lotus flowers so beautiful that it is fit for the heavenly inhabitants, singing birds, beautiful bees. He is not at all attracted by any of these because with one pointed attention he is determined to go to a place fit for him to sit and do meditation on the supreme lord as taught by the bhaktivedantas, his spiritual masters, when they were staying for four months during chaturmasya in that place in the forest where his mother was a maid servant. So somebody serious about spiritual life will never be attracted to any place which is meant for satisfying the senses. Any place which is meant for sense satisfaction, such a place has no attraction for a transcendentalist.

**Summary:** The role of a mendicant (parivrajaka acharya) is explained, emphasizing their duty to enlighten householders spiritually, rather than simply begging for food.

So in the purport, Srila Prabhupada explains it is the duty of a mendicant. Mendicant literally means a beggar, but it is taken in the sense of a spiritualist who lives a very simple life by being dedicated for spiritual practice, and for maintaining his body he simply begs for some little food from a householder. So such a mendicant is called a parivrajaka acharya. Parivrajaka means he is travelling constantly, wandering, and acharya means he is teaching. What is he teaching? He is teaching spiritual subject matter. He is awakening householders who are lost in material way of life to remind them about their spiritual goal in life. So he enlightens them, and on the plea of begging he goes to their house, but his real purpose of going to the house of a householder is not for begging, it is for enlightening them spiritually. Of course, in the Vedic culture, the householders welcome a sanyasi or a travelling mendicant or a transcendentalist. They welcome him home because they know that he brings in all auspiciousness, but the real purpose of a sanyasi is not to beg. So just to satisfy some householders, he may take a little food, may take, may not take, but his main purpose is how to enlighten the householder in spiritual subject matter which is the prime necessity for every human being.

Briefly I will just mention what are the stages of sanyas. Kutichaka is when one decides to renounce connection with family members, leaves home, but not yet practiced how to maintain himself independently, so he builds a cottage outside his village and he receives food from home. He is cut off from the family members, social interaction, but as far as his food requirement is concerned, it is taken care of by the family, former family members. When he is practiced in that way, then he realizes how he can actually maintain himself very easily by begging a little from many different houses, so nobody will feel a burden for weeding one person a little bit, collecting little, little from many houses, then nobody feels the burden and the person is very easily able to get his necessity of daily food, and so that's called bahudhaka, the second stage of sanyas where one is not dependent only on his one home, the former purvashram family residence, but begs little from the different people of the village outside which he is staying, and in that way very easily he maintains himself, his requirement of food. Then when he becomes further well established in sanyas, then he starts actually travelling. Travelling is for gaining strength of mind, faith in God, and enlighten the inhabitants as he is passing through different towns, villages, or settlements, human settlements like that. So these three things are particularly mentioned here: travelling alone, travelling alone to become fearless because a sanyasi knows that God is in my heart and he is my top most well wisher, he is my protector, he is my maintainer. Only due to illusion somebody may think that I have to depend on somebody else or something else outside of me. Actually one's dependence should be on the supreme lord seated in the heart who is always accompanying every person and is providing, maintaining, is actually taking care of the well being. It is only this supreme lord who does so. This is the purpose of a sanyasi.

### transcendental form of the Lord, mind's desire, mental incongruities, Narada Muni's experience
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xoI1iFCIR8g?t=58
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy

**Key Quote:** "The transcendental form of the Lord, as it is, satisfies the mind's desire and at once erases all mental incongruities."
**Summary:** This segment explains the meaning of the verse, focusing on how the transcendental form of the Lord satisfies the mind and removes mental incongruities, as experienced by Narada Muni.

In this session, we will be discussing from the 18th verse of the 6th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam: रूपं भगवतो यत्तन मनकान्तं शुचापहं अपश्यन सहत सोतस्थे वैक्लव्या दुर्मना इवा. The meaning of this verse is: "The transcendental form of the Lord, as it is, satisfies the mind's desire and at once erases all mental incongruities. Upon losing that form, I suddenly got up, being perturbed, as is usual, when one loses that which is desirable." So, Srila Nargumuni is explaining his experience to Vyasa Deva from his previous life. He began meditation. He had a glimpse of the Lord, and he became overjoyed with ecstasy. Suddenly, he lost that form. So then, after losing sight of that form, after getting a brief glimpse of darshan of that form of the Lord in the heart, Nargumuni is describing what was the kind of loss that he really felt when he lost sight of the Lord. The transcendental form of the Lord, as it is, satisfies the mind's desire. The mind is the center of all the senses, and the mind is driving the senses towards sense objects, looking for something. What is that something that each one of us is looking for? It is actually Krishna. Everyone is looking for Krishna, having forgotten Him, and also desiring to get back that which we have lost. The most desirable, the most beautiful, the most wonderful, the dear most, the dearest, we have lost that, so we are looking for that. So therefore, when we actually get darshan of the transcendental form of the Lord, then immediately our mind's desire is completely satisfied. And also, all the mental incongruities are erased, means in the mind we settle for something when we don't get what we are really looking for, and we think maybe this can satisfy me, but then we find something else which may be relatively either better or more beautiful or more pleasing for the mind, again it creates in the mind a kind of complex situation that maybe this is what I was looking for, no no no, this is not what I was looking for. So there are so many mental incongruities essentially established through contact with so many other forms other than the form of the Lord, so all these incongruities in the mind are completely erased when we actually get darshan of the form of the Lord.

### Narada Muni's experience, form of the Lord, material vs. spiritual form, limitations of material vision, Nirakar
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xoI1iFCIR8g?t=304
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Nirakar means the Lord does not have a material form."
**Summary:** This segment discusses Narada Muni's experience of seeing the Lord's form, contrasting it with the common understanding of God being formless (Nirakar), and clarifying that Nirakar means the Lord doesn't have a material form, but a transcendental one, which cannot be seen with material eyes.

And that's what Narad Muni is describing here. So he says, "I lost that form which was completely satisfying to my mind, which erased the form of the Lord, which erased all my mental incongruities, that form I lost." And suddenly, on losing the form, all of a sudden I lost that form, then I became very much perturbed in my mind, and that is to be expected because when somebody loses something which is very, very desirable, then how do they feel? That's how I felt. So, Shrila Prabhupada makes a very important point in the purport here that the Lord is not formless, is experienced by Narad Muni. A widely prevalent understanding about God is that God is formless, Nirakar. Nirakar is one of the terms that is used to describe God. It is one of the terms that is used to describe the Lord's features, but we should carefully understand what this Nirakar means. Nirakar means the Lord does not have a material form. He doesn't have a form made of flesh and blood and skin and bones. No, He doesn't have such a form. He has a transcendental form. He has a completely spiritual form. That form cannot be seen with these ordinary eyes. These eyes are suitable only for seeing some material forms. Even material forms which are very big we cannot see. Material forms which are too close to the eye we cannot see. We cannot see even our own eyelids. We can't see something very small. We can't see if there is no light to see a particular object or a form. So, these eyes have got limitations. In any case, even if we overcome all kinds of limitations of this eye by some mechanical means, material means, still, spiritual form can never be seen by any material adjustment even for these eyes. You cannot see spiritual form with material vision, even making adjustments.

So, Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport that there is no mechanical process to see the Lord, and it completely depends upon the causeless mercy of the Lord. This word causeless means Lord will not give darshan because you are doing something good. ### purity, material contamination, modes of nature
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/TqNMFlPuMuw?t=54
**Verse References:** BG 10.12-13
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "So there is no trace of a tinge of materiality in this person."
**Summary:** The Lord is completely pure and free from material contamination, unlike us who are influenced by the illusory energy, leading to a material conception of self and the world.

In this session we will be discussing from the first canto, 6th chapter, 21st verse of the Srimad Bhagavatam. हन्तास्मिन् जन्मनी भवान् मामाम् द्रष्टुम् इहार्हती अविपक्व कशायाणाम् दुर्दर्शोहं कुयोगिनाम् The meaning of this verse is, O Narada, the Lord is speaking to Narada, I regret that during this lifetime you will not be able to see me anymore. Those who are incomplete in service, and who are not completely free from all material taints, can hardly see me. Now here the Lord is explaining to Narada that Narada is not yet freed from all material taints. That's why one cannot see in spite of all sincerity, sincere attempts and endeavours. So Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport, the personality of Godhead is described in the Bhagavad Gita as the most pure. In the 10th chapter, Param Brahma Param Dhama Pavitram Paramam Bhavan. Pavitram means pure. Paramam Bhavan Paramam Pavitram, Supreme pure, complete pure, 100% pure. And he is described also as the supreme and the absolute truth, Param Brahma. So there is no trace of a tinge of materiality in this person. Unlike our personality, right now, in the material world, there is a contamination of materiality in this person. So that is the categorization of this personality. There is a contamination of the illusory influence of the material energy in our consciousness, and that's why we have a material conception of our self, of everything. Whereas the Lord, even when he comes to this material world, He is 100% pure, completely spiritual. There's no tinge of any materiality in this personality. But he is giving us this materiality, the same materiality that the Lord gave us. Even though he appears like a person who is created being of this world, he appears like that, son of Devaki, or he appears in his incarnation as Matsyavatara, he appears as a fish, but he is not touched by the material energy. It's not a material form, it's not a material creation. He comes in his original transcendental form only, though he appears as required, whichever form he desires to appear, to incarnate, to give darshan to his devotees, to mitigate the problems, the sufferings of his devotees, Paritranaya sadhuna. So, therefore, it is said here, thus, one who has the slightest tinge of material affection cannot approach him. So, this is conversely also explained that the Lord doesn't have any tinge of materiality and those in this material world who have any tinge of material affection cannot approach him. Not possible. The beginning of devotional service starts from the point when one is freed from at least two forms of material modes, namely the modes of passion and ignorance. The result is exhibited by the signs of being freed from karma and lobha. Karma means lust, lobha means greed or covetousness. That is to say, one must be freed from the desires for sense satisfaction and the avarice for sense gratification. Generally material conception of life is I am seeking satisfaction of my senses and I am also desirous or greedy for getting more of sense enjoyment. These two things, kama and lobha, are the symptoms of rajas and tamas.

To be completely freed from all material tinges is to become free from the mode of goodness also. As you know there are three gunas, three modes, rajas, tamas and sattva guna. As is explained elsewhere, a liquor shop is in the mode of ignorance, tamas guna. And a city is in the mode of passion, as a place, talking of different places, influence in different places. And a forest is considered to be in the mode of goodness or sattvic place. One can go into the forest to attain spiritual perfection, but that does not mean that one can see the Lord personally there. Just because I go to the forest, and the forest is in the mode of goodness, simply by attempting to do some meditation or some spiritual practice there, we cannot see the Lord, simply like that. One must be completely freed from all material attachment, and be situated on the plane of transcendence. We have to rise above tamas guna, rajas guna and sattva guna, and come to the plane of transcendence, shuddha sattva, purified goodness, or transcendental platform. This alone will help the devotee to get in personal touch with the personality of God. Because the Lord is on the spiritual platform, unless we rise to the spiritual platform and become fixed up, we will not be able to see the Lord.

**Summary:** Deity worship in the temple is a transcendental practice, superior to other forms of spiritual practice, especially in Kali Yuga, because the Lord manifests in the deity form out of His causeless mercy.

The best method is that one should live at a place where the transcendental form of the Lord is worshipped. Now here Srila Prabhupada explains the importance of the deity form of the Lord in the temple, or even at one's home. The deity form is completely a spiritual form, though it appears like a material form. After all, the deity is made out of stone, or wood, or metal. But that doesn't mean it is a metallic form, or a clay form, or a stone form. No, it is not. The deity is not a material form. Why? Because the deity is also called Archamurti, or Archavigraha. The Lord is invited after the form of the Lord is prepared, according to Shastra. And then, by the mercy of the bona fide spiritual master, or the Acharya, the Lord agrees to come and reside in that form, and accept the worship, the service, the devotional service, agrees to give darshan to even people who don't have spiritual vision. That is the causeless mercy of the Lord. That's the mercy of the transcendental form of the Lord in his form as the deity. The temple of the Lord is a transcendental place, whereas the forest is a materially good habitation. This difference exists, that a temple of the Lord where the deity form is worshipped regularly is completely a transcendental place. It's not different from Vaikuntha. Whereas the forest is a place which is in the mode of goodness, a sattvic place. So, forest still there is some material influence, but in the temple, it is completely a spiritual place. There is no material influence in the temple, just because of the presence of the archavigraha. Devotional service begins from the process of archana, which is better than going out in the forest, especially for us in Kali Yuga, where we are not equipped to do meditation, where we are not properly equipped or not prepared to properly undergo studies, properly engage in other forms of yoga other than bhakti yoga.

Either you directly worship, or if you are unable to worship, then you participate in the worship of the Lord in the temple. That's what you should do. The very fact that we can repeatedly chant day after day, week after week, month after month, year after year, and increase, keep increasing the chanting itself is proof that this is spiritual sound and therefore it increases.

### Material World, Spiritual World, Vaikuntha Planets
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/7wUSRHAOCp8?t=257
**Verse References:** BG 9.4
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Newcomers, General public
**Key Quote:** "And contains unlimited self-illuminated Vaikuntha planets."
**Summary:** This segment explains the three divisions of the material world, the spiritual sky with Vaikuntha planets, and the difference between living entities in the material and spiritual worlds, drawing from Bhagavad Gita.

In the purport, Srila Prabhupada says, as stated in the Bhagavad Gita, there are three divisions of the material spheres. This entire material universe, there are three divisions: Urdhva Loka, the upper planetary systems; Madhya Loka, the middle planetary systems. We are in the middle planetary system on the earth planet. And downward, below the earth, that is Adho Loka. Now, beyond the Urdhva Loka, beyond the upper planetary systems of which the Brahma Loka is the topmost in this universe, there are the material coverings of the universe. This whole universe is like a shell, Brahma Anda. It's called Brahma Anda, egg-shaped, Anda, therefore. And outside this shell, there are seven layers of coverings. And above this universe with its coverings, outside that, is the spiritual sky. And the spiritual sky is described as unlimited in expansion. Material sky is limited within the universal shell, whereas the spiritual sky is spread throughout, unlimited expansion, and contains unlimited self-illuminated Vaikuntha planets. Now, Vaikuntha planets are spiritual planets, unlike the material planets within the material universe. And these Vaikuntha planets are inhabited by God himself, along with his associates, who are all eternally liberated living entities. There are living entities in this material world. There are living entities in the spiritual world.

### Absolute Truth, Relative Truth, Material vs. Spiritual
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/lVBk_IkI5HY?t=184
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Newcomers, General public
**Key Quote:** "Absolute Truth is Truth which is... Truth in all phases of time. Past, Present and Future."
**Summary:** The speaker defines Absolute Truth as unchanging and contrasts it with Relative Truth, which is subject to change in the material world, using the example of a person residing in a house.

The very opening verse, it is said by Vyasadeva, the author of the Bhagavatam, that I meditate upon Shri Krishna because he is the Absolute Truth. सत्यं परं धीमही. सत्यं परं सत्यं परं सत्यं is truth. परं there indicates Absolute Truth. So what is this Absolute Truth? Absolute Truth is Truth which is... Truth in all phases of time: past, present, and future. The Truth is always the Truth. It doesn't change. Relative Truth is Truth which is not true in all phases of time. Every Truth in the material world of some material object or material activity is a Relative Truth. If... To give an example, if I say such and such a gentleman is residing in a particular apartment or house. Now this statement is a Relative Truth because what happens with time, in course of time, that gentleman who's staying in a particular house, when he passes away, when he changes body, when he dies, then that statement, 'such and such a gentleman residing in the house,' is no longer true. Then we are to say he was residing, and when he died, he is no longer residing in the house, or even when he shifts from that residence due to whatever reason to another residence, then that statement, 'such a gentleman is residing in this house,' is no longer true. So like this, every statement we make about a material phenomenon in this world is a relative truth. It is relative to time, whereas the absolute personality of Godhead Krishna is absolute truth. ### yoga, devotional service, sense control, soul satisfaction
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/VYxhbcV1ixE?t=59
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "yoga system is helpful to actually control the senses but it is not effective in giving satisfaction to the soul"
**Summary:** Narada Muni explains that while yoga can control the senses, it doesn't provide soul satisfaction, which comes from devotional service.

In this session, we will be discussing from the 35th verse of the 6th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. We are continuing the conversation between Narada and Vyasa Deva. Towards the end of the chapter, a few more verses, the chapter will conclude. So the 35th verse is, the meaning of this verse is, it is true that by practicing restraint of the senses by the yoga system, one can get relief from the disturbances of desire and lust, but this is not sufficient to give satisfaction to the soul, for this satisfaction is derived from devotional service to the Personality of Godhead. So Srila Narada Muni is clearly explaining that the yoga system is helpful to actually control the senses, but it is not effective in giving satisfaction to the soul. Ultimately, we are always seeking satisfaction of the soul, though we do not know it, especially those in ignorance of the spiritual nature of the self. They are unaware that the satisfaction of the senses, mind, or intelligence is not satisfaction of the soul. I, the real person, am different from the body or the senses. I am different from the mind. I am different from my intelligence. I am spirit, so this spirit requires spiritual satisfaction, soul satisfaction. So that is explained very nicely by Srila Prabhupada in the purport: yoga aims at controlling the senses. This is one of the main purposes of practicing yoga, to control the senses. Generally, our senses are totally uncontrolled in the sense, with the idea that whatever the senses demand, we are simply busy satisfying those demands, but that is not the way of spiritual life. So in yoga practice, there is by practice of the mystic process of bodily exercise in sitting, thinking, feeling, willing, concentrating, facing, and setting away, meditating and, as beam bus into trance and in this one can control the senses. So this, they call it eight-fold yoga system, Ashtanga Yoga: yama, niyama, asana, pranayama, na para nayam, pratyahara, dharana, dhyana, samadhi. Samadhi is completely being merged into transcendence. But the scriptures also describe this method of controlling the senses through yoga practice, Ashtanga Yoga practice. About that, the scriptures are telling, the senses are considered like venomous serpents, and the yoga system is just to control them. Narad Muni is recommending another method for controlling the senses. What is that? The method of transcendental loving service of Mukunda, the Personality of Godhead, the system of Bhakti, the process of Bhakti. It is different than the Ashtanga Yoga process.

### Ashtanga Yoga, devotional service, sense engagement, Krishna Consciousness
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/VYxhbcV1ixE?t=338
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Ashtanga Yoga is denying the sense satisfaction, denying mind satisfaction, denying intellectual satisfaction all this by forcibly restraining the senses"
**Summary:** The speaker contrasts Ashtanga Yoga's artificial method of denying sense gratification with devotional service's positive engagement of the senses in spiritual activities.

By his experience, Narad Muni says that devotional service to the Lord is more effective and practical than the system of artificially controlling the senses. The method of Ashtanga Yoga is an artificial method. That means you have to force yourself against your natural way of living, whereby you engage your senses in sense satisfaction in some activity aimed at either satisfying the senses or the mind or the intelligence. So Ashtanga Yoga is denying the sense satisfaction, denying mind satisfaction, denying intellectual satisfaction, all this by forcibly restraining the senses, holding back the senses from their sense objects, holding back the mind, not indulging the mind or the senses or the intelligence, whereas what happens in devotional service? In the service of the Lord Mukunda. Mukunda means another name for Krishna. The senses are transcendentally engaged. This is the big difference. It is not stopping the senses, it is engaging the senses, but in a different way. What is that different way? Spiritually engaging them, transcendentally engaging them. That means we do spiritual activities in Krishna Consciousness. That is the system of Krishna Consciousness, the system of Bhakti. We engage the senses in spiritual activities, just like you may like to hear a very melodious Kirtan, Hare Krishna Kirtan. That is transcendentally engaging your ears and your mind and even your intelligence, or you may relish tasting nice Krishna Prasadam. That is engagement for the tongue, the mind, the intelligence, everything. So it is positive engagement. Bhakti is positive engagement, of course, in a specific type of activity, spiritual activity, and there are varieties, there is variety, ample variety of spiritual activities. In this way, if the senses are transcendentally engaged while serving Lord Mukunda, Lord Krishna, there is no chance of the senses being engaged in sense gratification, no chance. And the important point to notice, the senses want some engagement. They cannot be kept for long without any activity. That is artificial. To check them artificially is no check at all, because as soon as there is some opportunity for enjoyment, the serpent-like senses will certainly take advantage of it.

### sense control, Vishwamitra Muni, Haridas Thakur, devotional service, Maya
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/VYxhbcV1ixE?t=556
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "a devotee who is engaged in devotional service cannot be allured by Maya because this is a superior engagement"
**Summary:** The speaker uses the examples of Vishwamitra Muni and Haridas Thakur to illustrate the difference between artificial sense control and the power of devotional service to overcome Maya.

And Prabhupada gives a nice example. There are many such instances in history, and they have been recorded in the Puranas, in the scriptures, just like the example is given of Vishwamitra Muni. He was a great king. He renounced his kingdom and all the wealth and the comforts, royal comforts, and he went away to a forest, a secluded place, and he was performing tapasya. But he, while practicing tapasya, Vishwamitra Muni became a victim to the beauty of Menaka. Whenever any great personality is very determined to perform tapasya, Indra, the king of heaven, he becomes very worried that this person who is doing tapasya may overtake me and replace me as the king of heaven. So Indra sends Apsaras to disturb the tapasya, and that's what exactly happened when Vishwamitra Muni was sitting in the forest and performing meditation. Indra sent one Apsara by name Menaka, and Menaka came and she allured Vishwamitra Muni, and Vishwamitra Muni became completely distracted from his tapasya. But the other example that is also given, a devotee of Lord Chaitanya Thakur, Haridas, he was allured at midnight by the well-dressed Maya. Maya Devi herself came to allure Haridas Thakur when he was sitting and chanting Hare Krishna. Still, she could not induce him into her trap. She could not do that. In fact, Maya Devi surrendered to Haridas Thakur and begged for the holy name from him. So a devotee who is engaged in devotional service cannot be allured by Maya because this is a superior engagement. This is explained in the Bhagavad Gita, param drishtva nivartate. If you want to stop the senses from being engaged in mundane sense activities, then you should engage the senses in devotional service, and such engagement is superior.

### devotional service, yoga, jnana, karma, self-realization
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/VYxhbcV1ixE?t=736
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "without devotional service of the Lord neither the yoga system nor philosophical speculation can ever become successful"
**Summary:** The speaker emphasizes that pure devotional service is the topmost path to self-realization, superior to yoga, jnana, and karma, and that these other paths are dependent on bhakti.

You cannot be distracted by Maya. The whole idea is that without devotional service of the Lord, neither the yoga system nor philosophical speculation can ever become successful. Always yoga means karma, karma yoga, jnana, jnana yoga, tapasya, ashtanga yoga, they are different. Whenever the word yoga is suffixed to karma, jnana, or tapasya, then it means that you have to mix with devotional service. Now, pure devotional service of the Lord is without any tinge of or without any mixture of fruity work, mystic yoga, or speculative philosophy, without any mixture of karma, jnana, or tapasya, that without any mixture of that, pure devotional service is actually the foremost procedure for self-realization. This will be explained in detail in the later portions of the Bhagavatam. Such pure devotional service is transcendental in nature, and the systems of yoga and jnana are subordinate to such a process. Yoga and jnana are dependent on mixture of bhakti, whereas pure bhakti is independent of yoga, jnana, karma, everything else. When the transcendental devotional service is mixed with a subordinate process, it is no longer transcendental. It is called mixed devotional service. So all this will be explained by Sri Vyasadeva in the text later on, but for now Narada Muni is telling, bhakti can give complete satisfaction for the soul. Yoga can help in controlling the senses, but it cannot give satisfaction for the soul. Therefore, he is recommending bhakti over the process of yoga or even the process of jnana or even karma. So bhakti, pure devotional service, is the topmost.

So, what does Krishna take away that he is referred to as Hari? He takes away all inauspicious things from his devotees. Isn't it so nice? Of course, this doesn't refer to devotees who are already free from all bad qualities or all inauspiciousness. It refers to devotees who are on the path, just entering the path of pure devotional service and very quickly they become purified by coming in touch with the Supreme Lord Krishna. The second meaning of the word Hari in this context of its usage in this Atmarama verse is that he attracts the mind by ecstatic love for God. In this way, when all sinful activities are vanquished by the grace of the Supreme Personality of Godhead, one gradually vanquishes all kinds of impediments on the path of devotional service, as well as the ignorance resulting from these impediments. In the path of Bhakti, these material contaminations are obstacles. Now as one goes on rendering devotional service to Krishna, the heart becomes cleansed automatically without separate endeavour, and impediments are all gone, the obstacles are removed. And when the obstacles are removed, even the ignorance is vanquished. One becomes enlightened from within automatically without separate endeavour. After this, one totally manifests his original love of Godhead through devotional service in nine different ways, hearing, chanting, remembering, etc. When the devotee is freed from all sinful material activities, Krishna attracts his body, mind and senses to perform devotional service to him. See, as long as there is material contamination, we have attraction for so many material things. But when the material contamination is gone, we get attracted to Krishna. And Krishna attracts our total being, our body, our mind, our words, everything completely. Krishna attracts. And thus it is described, Krishna is very, very merciful and his transcendental qualities are very attractive. He is full of so many transcendental qualities. Now further, Lord Chaitanya explains, when one's mind, senses and body are attracted to the transcendental qualities of the Supreme Lord Hari, one gives up the four principles of material success. What are the four principles of material success? Dharma, Artha, Karma, Moksha. Dharma means religious performance. Artha means economic development. Karma means sense gratification. And Moksha means liberation.

**Summary:** The speaker discusses the concept of absolute truth (Brahma) and identifies Krishna as the Supreme Personality of Godhead, the absolute truth that exists in all phases of time.

So, generally people who are pious in this material world, they are interested in four goals of a civilized human being, mentioned in the Shastra: Dharma, Artha, Karma, Moksha. But Bhakti is greater than these four Purusharthas. Bhakti is called the Panchama Purushartha, the fifth goal of a human being, of a living being. So, when a devotee becomes attracted by Krishna and begins to render devotional service, automatically such a devotee loses interest in Dharma, Artha, Karma, Moksha. Those four Purusharthas don't interest the devotee anymore. Completely, the devotee rises above these four Purusharthas. Now, the next set of meanings that Lord Chaitanya explains. The word Brahma indicates the Samambonam, the absolute truth, which is greater than all other truths. In this material world, whatever we know as truth is called relative truth. And Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, is the absolute truth. What is absolute truth? Absolute truth is truth in all phases of time, under all circumstances, in all conditions. Whereas relative truth is not truth in all phases of time. It is the original identity, Brahma means the original identity, and there can be nothing equal to that absolute truth. So, there is a definition of this absolute truth as Brahma in the Vishnu Purana. It is stated there, I offer my respectful obeisances to the absolute truth, the Samambonam. He is the all-pervasive, all-increasing subject matter for the great yogis. He is changeless, and he is the soul of all, the soul of all souls, the super soul, the supreme soul. Actually, the proper meaning of the word Brahma is the Supreme Personality of Godhead, who is one without a second, and without whom nothing else exists.

Now, Krishna is realized through three processes, the Absolute Truth. Krishna means the Absolute Truth is realized through three processes: the process of philosophical speculation, the process of performing Ashtanga, you call it a mystic yoga process, and the process of devotional service. So Lord Chaitanya has learned this. So Lord Chaitanya is now explaining, although the words Brahma and Aatma indicate Krishna, their direct meanings refer only to the impersonal Brahma and the super soul respectively. Brahma means impersonal Brahman. Atma means the super-soul in the heart of every living being. So why the distinction is being made now is, because if one follows the path of philosophical speculation, Gyanamarga, the Absolute Truth manifests Himself as impersonal Brahman. That means through the Jnana Marga one cannot realize Krishna simply by following the Jnana Marga. The topmost possible realization of the Absolute Truth through Jnana Marga is only the impersonal Brahman. If one follows the path of Mystic Yoga, Ashtanga Yoga system, he manifests himself as a Supersoul. So through Ashtanga Yoga only the Paramatma can be realized, only the Paramatma. But through devotional service one realizes Krishna, the personality of Godhead Bhagavan. In the Bhagavatam it is explained there are three features: the Absolute Truth, the impersonal Brahman, the localized Paramatma or the Supersoul, and ultimately the personality of Godhead Bhagavan. So among these three features, realization of Bhagavan, the personality of Godhead is the highest realization and that includes the other two realizations of Brahman and Paramatma.

And he was ready to kill more animals. This hunter was having a black complexion, a dark complexion. He had reddish eyes. And he appeared very, very fierce. He was like the superintendent of death. He was like the superintendent of death. Yamarath standing there with bow and arrows in his hands to kill so many more animals. Now Narada Muni, he left the path which was there in the forest. And he went to the hunter who was hiding behind a tree to kill more animals. And as soon as Narada Muni approached the hunter, so many animals, they started running away. The hunter, he wanted to chastise Narada Muni with abusive language, that you spoiled my whole arrangement for killing animals. But when Narada Muni came closer to the hunter, due to Narada Muni's divine association or divine presence, that hunter restrained his tongue and did not abuse Narada Muni. He said, oh great saintly person, why are you leaving the general path and you are approaching me in this forest? Simply by seeing you, all the animals I was hunting have now run away. You have disturbed my occupation. So Narada Muni replied to this hunter, I have come to you to clear one doubt that is there in my mind. So Narada Muni asked that hunter, those animals which are half killed, three animals I saw. I saw a deer, I saw a boar, I saw a rabbit. Were you the one who actually shot those arrows and half killed those animals? The hunter replied, yes. Narada Muni inquired from this hunter, why are you not killing those animals completely? You are half killing them by piercing one arrow which does not fully kill them. Why are you doing like this? Then the hunter replied to Narada Muni, my name is Mrigari. Mrigari means I am the enemy of the animals. My father taught me how to kill in this way, half kill animals by piercing one arrow. And this hunter is telling Narada, when I see animals suffer due to pain, then I become very happy. So Narada Muni told this hunter, can I beg from you one thing? The hunter said, yes. What do you want? You want the skin of some animals, tiger skin, deer skin, I can give you. Narada Muni said, no, no, no. I do not want any skin from you. I want to request you that kindly don't half kill animals. You kill them completely, fully kill them. Don't half kill animals. So the hunter asked, what's the difference between half killing and fully killing the animals? So Narada Muni replied that when you half kill the animals, they suffer so much more pain than if you were to fully kill the animals. See, as a hunter, your business is to kill animals. Now that's an offense on your part, killing animals. But if you unnecessarily give them so much more pain by half killing them, you incur very great sin. So this is Narada Muni's divine influence on the hunter.

That never can happen. In the thirty-third verse, it is described, the meaning of this thirty-third verse is, "Arjuna, his eyes blazing in anger, like two red balls of copper, dexterously arrested the son of Gautami and bound him with ropes, like an animal. Pashumrashanayata." So, Arjuna was very angry against this Ashwatthama because Ashwatthama had killed the five sleeping sons of Draupadi. So, Arjuna was very angry against this. He was so angry against Ashwatthama. And therefore, Arjuna's description here is, his eyes blazing in anger like two red balls of copper. He was so angry, his red eyes had become so red. And Arjuna arrested this Ashwatthama. He did not kill him immediately. He arrested him. And how did he arrest him? He bound him up with ropes like an animal. Generally a human being is not bound up by ropes like that, but here the treatment meted out to Ashwatthama by Arjuna is justified by Srila Prabhupada in the purport. Srila Prabhupada says, "Ashwatthama's mother Krippi was born in the family of Gautama, so she is referred to as Gautami, and Ashwatthama is referred to as Gautami Sutam. The significant point in this shloka is that Ashwatthama was caught and bound up with ropes like an animal. According to Sridhar Swami, Arjuna was obliged to catch this son of a Brahmana like an animal as part of the ritual, as part of his duty, Dharma." So the Acharyas are explaining that Arjuna was just doing his duty.

### transcendence, divine anger, devotion
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/uTZ4IewLiuc?t=781
**Verse References:** SB 1.7.34
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Because Krishna is absolute, both his anger and pleasure are the same."
**Summary:** The speaker explains the difference between Arjuna's anger and Krishna's anger, emphasizing Krishna's transcendental nature and his concern for his devotees.

That's already described. In the Purport, Srila Prabhupada says that both Arjuna and Lord Sri Krishna are described here in angry mood, but Arjuna's eyes were like balls of red copper whereas the eyes of the Lord were like lotuses. What does this mean? This means that the angry mood of Arjuna and that of the Lord are not on the same level. Why? Because the Lord is transcendence and is absolute in any stage. Krishna is not affected by some moods or some influence of some event. He is unaffected under all circumstances at all times in all places. So he is transcendently situated, always, eternally. His anger, that is Krishna's anger, is not like the anger of a conditioned living being within the modes of qualitative material nature. When we become angry, we are influenced by the modes of material nature, Rajoguna, Tamoguna. Because Krishna is absolute, both his anger and pleasure are the same. His anger is not exhibited in the three modes of material nature. It is only a sign of his bent of mind towards the cause of his devotee, because that is his transcendental nature. Krishna felt for Arjuna because Ashwatthama had beheaded the sleeping sons of Draupadi. Draupadi is also Krishna's devotee. So Krishna was feeling for his devotee. Therefore, even if Krishna is angry, the object of anger is blessed. He is unchanged in all circumstances. This is Krishna's position. He is unaffected by any situation. He is always transcendently situated.

### dharma, brahmana, qualification
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xIhzblKD8I4?t=65

**Summary:** The speaker explains the meaning of verse 35, focusing on the term 'Brahma Bandhu' and emphasizing that being born in a Brahmin family does not automatically make one a Brahmana; qualifications are necessary.

The 35th verse: Mainam Partharhasitratum Brahma Bandhum Imamjahi Yosav Anagasa Suptan Avadheen Nishi Balakan. The meaning of this verse is: Lord Sri Krishna said, "O Arjuna, you should not show mercy by releasing this relative of a Brahmana, Brahma Bandhu, for he has killed innocent boys in their sleep." Krishna is justifying punishing Ashwatthama appropriately because Ashwatthama has killed innocent boys in their sleep. He is not observing the rules of Dharma Yudha. And he is being referred to as Brahma Bandhu, relative of a Brahmana. He is not a Brahmana. By his actions, he has proved otherwise. So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada says, "The word Brahma Bandhu is significant." Ashwatthama being referred to as Brahma Bandhu is significant. A person who happens to take birth in the family of a Brahmana, but is not qualified to be called a Brahmana, is addressed as the relative of a Brahmana and not as a Brahmana. This is a very, very important point to be understood, that simply by birth in a Brahmin family, without qualification, nobody can become a Brahmana. Nobody can be called as a Brahmana. Brahmana is only if they are qualified, only if they have characteristics and qualities of a Brahmana.

### brahmana, qualification, shastra
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xIhzblKD8I4?t=282
**Verse References:** BG 18.42
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The Shastra enjoins that even if good qualifications are seen in a person born in a family, other than that of a Brahmana, the qualified man has to be accepted as a Brahmana."
**Summary:** The speaker explains that the shastras state that a person with Brahmanical qualities should be accepted as a Brahmana regardless of birth, and conversely, one born in a Brahmin family without the qualities should not be considered a Brahmana.

This is the Shastric injunction, but it is not understood properly or not enforced properly in modern times. The Shastra enjoins that even if good qualifications are seen in a person born in a family other than that of a Brahmana, the qualified man has to be accepted as a Brahmana. Yesiyal lakshanam proktam. That whatever the qualities that are seen in a particular person, irrespective of his birth in some family. Let's say somebody is born in a Vaishya family, but the person displays all qualities of a Brahmana, he has to be accepted as a Brahmana. That's what it is telling. The Shastras say like that. Similarly, if a person born in the family of Brahmana is void of Brahmanical qualification, he must be treated as a non-Brahmana, or in better terms, a relative of a Brahmana, Brahmabandhu. So, without qualification, nobody should be addressed as a Brahmana. And, there is sometimes protest by the so-called Brahmanas. If somebody born in a Vaishya family is referred to as a Brahmana because the person is qualified as a Brahmana, the others will protest. Lord Shri Krishna, the supreme authority of all religious principles, the Vedas, has personally pointed out these differences. Krishna actually explains this in several places, in several occasions, in stances, that only by qualification, we can call somebody a Brahmana.

No. He is not absolved of that sin of animal killing. So the person who gives permission, the person who kills the animal, obviously he is liable to be punished. He who sells the slaughtered animal, after the animal is killed, that flesh is sold for those who want to eat meat, animal flesh. He who cooks the animal, somebody is going to cook that meat, because human beings don't eat raw flesh, unlike tigers and lions and all those carnivorous animals, human beings eat cooked flesh. So somebody is cooking that flesh. And those who administer distribution of this cooked meat, somebody is engaged in distributing it. And at last, the person who eats cooked animal food are all murderers. Six types of people are liable to be punished when animal killing happens in a civilized human society. All of them are liable to be punished, by the laws of nature. Why? Because no one can create a living being despite all advancement of material science, and therefore, no one has the right to kill a living being by one's independent wills. We cannot create life, so we cannot kill.

### Shabda Vedi, Maharaj Dasaratha, Ramayana, mistake, consequences
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/cgnQKK7lYx8?t=178
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "He could pierce his target with his arrow by only hearing the sound without seeing the object."
**Summary:** The speaker narrates the story of Maharaj Dasaratha and his mastery of Shabda Vedi, the art of hitting a target by sound, and how he accidentally killed a Brahmachari named Shravan Kumar, leading to negative consequences.

To target a particular person when you release a weapon. That is lost now. That science is lost. So in the Ramayana, it is said that Maharaj Dasaratha, the father of Lord Sri Rama used to control arrows by sound only. He could pierce his target with his arrow by only hearing the sound without seeing the object. So Srila Prabhupad explains, it is called Shabda Vedi. Just like I cannot see where is a bird, but the bird is chirping. And by Shabda Vedi, I can release an arrow. It will go wherever the bird is by the dint of the sound the bird is making. And it will go and kill that bird. So, this is called Shabda Vedi. Now Maharaja Dasharatha used it. He knew this science and he used it. And once he made a mistake of instead of killing an animal in the forest, he killed a boy, one Brahmachari. It is described in the Ramayana. Because that Brahmachari had come, he was taking his parents on a pilgrimage and they were old. He was carrying them in a palanquin and when they were thirsty on the way, so he stopped and he went to fetch water. So, he went looking for a water source and he found a pond with clear water. So, when he dipped that pot in the pond to get water, it made sound and this Dasharatha, was actually hiding. And when he heard that sound, he thought here is some animal that has come to drink water in the pond. So, he released an arrow aimed at whoever was actually making that sound while fetching water or drinking water. And the arrow went and actually pierced that Brahmachari. His name was Shravan Kumar. That is described in the Ramayana. And Shravan Kumar almost immediately was killed by the arrow released by Dasharatha. Then Dasharatha, after having released the arrow, when he heard a human being is crying out, then he went and saw, Oh, I have killed a Brahmachari. He never intended to kill a Brahmachari. No. But he mistook by the sound of that pot he was trying to fill. He mistook that sound to be the sound of an animal drinking water. And because he knew the science without seeing the target, He actually shot the arrow, Shabda Vedi, and it went and pierced that target. The Brahmachari who made that sound while filling the pot.

So it is explained by Srila Prabhupada in the purport, the wife of Dronacharya, Krippi, is a sister of Krippacharya, a devoted wife, who is according to the revealed scripture, the better half of her husband, is justified in embracing voluntary death along with her husband, if she is without issue. But in the case of the wife of Dronacharya, she did not undergo such a trial, because she had her son, the representative of her husband. So one who gives birth, Prajayate. Praja is the product of the body of the father. That's what Prabhupada explains. The father's body is actually present in the form of the son or daughter, Praja. The Shastra says, Yatha yoni yatha bijam. Father is the bijam. The seed is given by the father. And just like you sow a seed in the ground, then a huge tree comes up. So the seed itself is generated by the tree. But that seed again grows up to be a tree. So the seed is tree later on. Similarly, the seed is put by the father in the womb of the mother, implanted. And when you sow a seed in the ground, you take care for it to properly grow. Similarly, the seed is sown in the womb of the mother, and the mother takes care of the seed and becomes a big body and comes out. So this is the process of birth. In one sense, the seed and the tree there is no difference. Similarly, there is no difference between the son and the father. No difference. The seed of the father and the father himself, there is no difference. So Dronacharya is still present in the form of his son, Ashwathama. So according to Vedic culture, this is very important to understand. A woman who has got a son, even if her husband is dead, she is not considered a widow. ### Dharma, intrinsic nature, service, Krishna

**Summary:** The speaker defines Dharma not as a sectarian faith but as the intrinsic nature of something, using examples like fire, rivers, and sugar, and then states that the Dharma of a human being is to render service, specifically to Krishna.

Now religion should not be understood as some sectarian system of faith. Many times Srila Prabhupada explains this because that is a misconception in the society in general among the people, that when you say Dharma, immediately they take it like some kind of faith, some system. No, it is not a system of faith. Dharma is the eternal, inseparable, intrinsic nature of something. Like the Dharma of fire is heat and light. Wherever there is fire, there has to be heat and light. You cannot have fire where there is no heat. You cannot have fire where there is no light. Not possible. It is intrinsically the quality of fire. So Dharma of fire is heat and light. Dharma of a river is to flow. River means it keeps flowing, flowing, flowing till it reaches the ocean. So then only it is called a river, Nadi. And similarly, Dharma of sugar is the sweet taste of sugar. So you cannot have sugar which is not sweet in taste. Then it is not sugar. Sugar means it should be sweet in taste, and it gives that sweet taste to whatever you mix sugar with. It gives the sweet taste, right? So that, like that, what is the Dharma of a human being? Human being has got Dharma. What is the Dharma of the human being? So that is explained in the scriptures. Dharma of the human being is to render service, to render service. So one should render service to Krishna.

### dharma, scriptural injunctions, renunciation, duty, contradictions

**Verse References:** BG 18

**Key Quote:** "Whenever somebody tries to refer the scriptures, then in certain circumstances, to apply the scriptural injunction, it is difficult."
**Summary:** The lecture explores the difficulty in applying scriptural injunctions, using the example of a sanyasi's duties and the apparent contradictions within the scriptures.

So in the purport, Srila Prabhupada says that Arjuna was perplexed because Ashwatthama was to be killed as well as spared according to different scriptures cited by different persons. This is a fact. Whenever somebody tries to refer the scriptures, then in certain circumstances, to apply the scriptural injunction, it is difficult. In the 18th chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, it is explained that for somebody who is a sanyasi, who is in the renounced order of life, there are no duties to be performed. No duties to be performed because he is completely renounced. He is simply engaged in devotional service to Krishna, exclusively dedicated for that. That is the meaning of renunciation. At the same time, Shastra says that activities which are of the nature of yajna, dana and tapa should never be given up under any circumstances. For a civilized human being, in all stages, one should never stop performing sacrifice because sacrifice is specifically activity meant for pleasing the Supreme Lord. So, in that way, we can understand sacrifice should never be given up. Though, material activities, or material duties even, a sanyasi has got no material duties. A brahmachari has got duties, a grihasta has got duties, a vanapurasta has got duties, but a sanyasi has no material duties. So, it is difficult to understand whether a sanyasi should perform any activities, or not do any activities at all. So, like this, in the scriptures, there are injunctions which seemingly are contradictory in certain circumstances, in certain situations where one has to apply. Different people will give different circumstances, cite different shastras and give different rulings.

Now, Srila Prabhupada further explains, what does it mean? This statement suggests that the complete unit of the personality of Godhead includes his parts and parcels also. The Lord is always complete, and he is never without his parts and parcels. He saw therefore, what all did he see? He saw therefore his different energies, namely the internal energy, the marginal energy, and the external energy. The Lord is always with his energies, so Vyasadeva, when he saw the Lord, he saw his different energies also. He also saw his different plenary portions and parts of the plenary portions, namely his different incarnations also. Even though the Supreme Lord is one, one and only Supreme Personality of Godhead, but he is not a limited person. He has many different forms of incarnations, plenary portions, parts of plenary portions, and Vyasadeva also specifically observed the unwanted miseries of the conditioned souls who are bewildered by the external energy. This was explained in the previous verse, and here the remedial measure is given, and at last he saw the Lord, and here the remedial measure is given, and at last he saw the Lord, and at last he saw the Lord, and at last he saw the remedial measure for the conditioned souls, namely the process of devotional service. This is the perfect remedy for the suffering of the conditioned souls. What is it? It is the process of devotional service. This devotional service is a great transcendental science and begins with the process of hearing and chanting, and begins with the process of hearing and chanting the name, fame, glory, etc. of the Supreme Personality of Godhead: shravanam, kirtanam, vishnom. This is the beginning of the process of devotional service.

### devotional service, sincerity, causeless mercy, mitigation of miseries
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/5PXy_ny0POc?t=370
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy

**Summary:** This segment emphasizes that devotional service should not be mechanical but involve the full mind and spirit, highlighting the importance of sincerity and the causeless mercy of the Lord in bestowing love of God, and noting the immediate mitigation of material miseries as a benefit of devotional service.

Revival of the dormant affection or love of Godhead does not depend on the mechanical system of hearing and chanting. Generally, people, when they do something repeatedly, the process tends to become mechanical, just like routinely we do so many things very mechanically. But the process of devotional service is never a mechanical process because it is the full involvement of the mind, because it is the full involvement of the mind, the full involvement of the spirit soul, of the spiritual personality, 100% involved in this process, then only the process is effective to the extent of achieving perfection. Even if somebody does devotional service in a mechanical way, there is benefit, there is a benefit, but it is not sufficient to take us to perfection. So Shrila Prabhupada says this transcendental process, it solely and wholly depends on the causeless mercy of the Lord. Bhakti is something that is bestowed by the Supreme Lord. When the Lord is fully satisfied with the sincere efforts of the devotee, he may endow him with his loving transcendental service. So the complete perfection comes after the devotee has rendered devotional service with all his efforts, sincerely trying to please the Lord, and when the Lord is pleased, he bestows the perfection of love of God. But even with the prescribed forms of hearing and chanting, that is just one has begun, there is at once mitigation of the superfluous and unwanted miseries of material existence. The effect on the heart of the chanting and hearing is immediately felt even by the beginner before he is able to even make advancement. Immediately, what is the immediate effect? The mitigation of material miseries. This is very important to understand, and it is a very great encouragement for anyone that immediately they begin to feel the benefit of this process.
