### knowledge vs. devotion, purification, material contamination, spiritual satisfaction
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/5PXy_ny0POc?t=570
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Devotion helps us to awaken knowledge within our heart."
**Summary:** The speaker contrasts the path of knowledge with the path of devotion, stating that devotion is independent of knowledge and helps awaken it, and emphasizes the need for purification from material contamination accumulated over lifetimes to experience transcendental love, explaining that material miseries are superfluous and the material body is unwanted.

Such mitigation of material affection does not wait for development of transcendental knowledge. This is what the impersonalists think, that unless there is knowledge, there is no progress in spiritual life. That is for the jnana process. Bhakti process does not depend on development of transcendental knowledge. So the Prabhupada says, rather knowledge is dependent on devotional service for the ultimate realization of the supreme truth. So knowledge is dependent on devotion, but devotion is independent of knowledge. Devotion helps us to awaken knowledge within our heart. So the process of devotional service, it directly acts on the contaminated consciousness to purify, but the devotee has to sincerely engage in the process and patiently engage in the process and patiently wait for complete purification. The complete purification takes some time because we have been associating with this material world for a very, very, very long time, millions of lifetimes, and we have accumulated so much of this material contamination life after life after life after life after life. In ignorance, we have been simply engaging in sense gratification, so that has to be cleansed away before we can actually experience the transcendental love in reciprocation with the Supreme Lord. Before that, we have to cleanse the heart. These material miseries are described as superfluous. Superfluous means they are actually not giving any benefit for us. They are simply useless stuff. That's why they are called un-earth. In fact, un-earth means unwanted, something which is unwanted. Un-earth, this body itself, material body itself is un-earth, it itself is un-earth. But in the material conception, we think we cannot exist without the body. Why? Because the body is the means for our sense gratification, for our material enjoyment. That material enjoyment, yes, we can have to whatever extent we can get some material pleasure by the means of the body, but as spirit soul, we are not meant to enjoy materially. Neither material pleasures give any satisfaction for the soul.

### soul's satisfaction, material vs. transcendental happiness, temporary vs. eternal bliss
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/5PXy_ny0POc?t=772
**Verse References:** BG 5.22
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Material pleasure is simply a sensation, and it is a temporary thing... and it eventually leads to miseries only; whereas transcendental happiness is completely pure bliss and it is never momentary."
**Summary:** This segment discusses the soul's true satisfaction, contrasting material pleasures, which are temporary and lead to misery, with transcendental happiness, which is pure, eternal bliss experienced through transcendental senses, referencing the Bhagavad Gita to support this point.

The Bhagavatam raises this point: what ensures that there is complete satisfaction for the soul? The satisfaction of the soul, of the real self, that is to be considered. The satisfaction of the soul is never possible by any material pleasure, material means, material methods, material pleasures, material arrangements. It never even touches the soul in any way. So therefore, people who are seeking real happiness, they are frustrated when they make different arrangements for enjoying materially, or they seek material happiness, and they never are satisfied within their heart, never are satisfied. So this point is explained in the Bhagavad Gita: yehi samsparishya ja bhoga dukha yonaya evate aadyantavan takaunteya nateshu ramate budhah. One more verse that explains what is the nature of transcendental happiness: sukham aatyantikam yatta buddhikrahyam atindriyam. You see, this transcendental happiness is an experience of boundless transcendental joy which is experienced with transcendental senses, atindriyam, not with this material senses. These material senses are useless for experiencing any any spiritual happiness or transcendental happiness. So material pleasure is simply a sensation, and it is a temporary thing. It is also called chapala sukha, momentary happiness, and it eventually leads to miseries only, whereas transcendental happiness completely pure bliss, and it is never momentary. So I will stop here. Thank you very much.

So, Srila Prabhupada has written an elaborate purport for this. Let us try to hear from Prabhupada what he says. So, Prabhupada begins his purport by telling, Shri Mati Kunti Devi was quite aware that Krishna is the original personality of Godhead, although he was playing the part of her nephew. See, Krishna when he incarnates, he plays the part of a particular person and yet he remains the supreme personality of Godhead under all situations and circumstances. His absolute position, supreme position does not change even though he may appear to be like Krishna, younger than Kunti Devi, subordinate to somebody else, but his supreme position is unchanged because he is the original personality of Godhead. The younger ones offer obeisances to the elders. But here Kunti, elderly lady, she is offering obeisances to somebody who is younger, many many years younger. So why? That is because Krishna is no ordinary person. He is the original personality of Godhead. Devi is addressing Krishna as the original Purusha beyond the material cosmos. We are all created beings within this material world, whereas Krishna exists beyond this material creation. He is beyond this material creation. And even beyond the material creation, though there are many many many liberated souls, devotees, Krishna is the original Purusha, original personality, original Lord. The meaning of this verse is, being beyond the range of limited sense perception, you are the eternally irreproachable factor covered by the curtain of deluding energy. We are getting knowledge from outside through these five senses. Krishna is beyond this range of our senses to perceive. Because Krishna's form is completely spiritual. So, these eyes cannot see spiritual form. These ears cannot hear spiritual sound. You see, that's why Krishna's personality is totally spiritual. And therefore, he is beyond the range of limited sense perception. Krishna is also described as the eternally irreproachable. In your case, Krishna is the irreproachable factor. Irreproachable means faultless. Krishna is eternally faultless. Whereas, one of the qualities of every living being is, the living being being very, very limited. Every living being being very limited is prone to commit mistakes. This is one of the characteristics of every living being. Even though, such great personalities like big big devatas, they also sometimes commit mistakes, so nobody is eternally faultless except Krishna. So, therefore Krishna is described here as eternally irreproachable factor, eternally faultless, and he is also covered by a curtain of deluding energy, maya javanika chanam. Krishna has got two kinds of energies which bewilders us. One kind of energy is the material energy which bewilders us, the maha maya. And another kind of energy Krishna has got which is called yoga maya, the spiritual energy that is also bewildering for every every living being. Both the spiritual energy which is personal energy of Krishna and Krishna's material energy, both are bewildering for the living entities. He sees the living being who is actually a spirit soul, spiritual by nature, completely different from the body. Krishna sees the soul. And that is also the vision of pure devotees. They see living beings as spirit souls trapped in a body, trapped in a misconception that they are seeking some material enjoyment in different ways. So it is important that to understand Krishna is easily accessible for the sincere soul who follows Krishna's instructions, the instructions of the devotional literature in simply approaching the Deity form of the Lord and just bowing down, Krishna, you are the Supreme Lord and I offer my respectful, sincere obeisances to you just because you are the Supreme Lord and you deserve the greatest respect in this world. So just this alone is enough for Krishna to reveal himself as the Supreme Personality of Godhead to a sincere soul. And in this regard, women are fortunate because without wasting time in trying to speculate and differentiate between matter and spirit and trying to philosophize, they simply bow down and they are recipients very easily of Krishna's mercy by which they can understand Krishna. I will stop here.

So, Sanatana Goswami, he had a touchstone with him and he had left this stone, touchstone in a pile of refuse, in some garbage. He had thrown it in the garbage. A needy man took it. He was considering that what kind of thing I have taken from the Goswami, from Sanatana. He therefore asked Sanatana Goswami for the most valuable thing. He was intelligent enough to understand, if touchstone is the most valuable thing Sanatana Goswami has in his possession, then he would not have left it in the garbage. ### material advancement, civilization, spiritual advancement, material miseries, Anartha, Krishna consciousness, pure devotees
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/JCME3k_SHaQ?t=795
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Material advancement is Anartha. It is not required."
**Summary:** The speaker concludes by stating that material advancement is an unwanted thing (Anartha) that leads to entanglement and misery, and encourages listeners to give it up and embrace Krishna consciousness under the guidance of pure devotees.

When somebody advances materially, material advancement is civilization. Such material advancement is a great stumbling block for spiritual advancement. The more one becomes materially advanced, the more one becomes puffed up, and consequently, such a puffed up person cannot make spiritual advancement even if such a person takes to chanting Hare Krishna, because the chanting will be done without the sincere feeling. That is not possible for a materially intoxicated person. Such material advancement entangles the living being in the bondage of material body followed by all sorts of material miseries. See, material advancement comes with a price. What is that? With material advancement, there is entanglement and entanglement means material miseries. So, this has to be carefully understood. So, therefore, in Sanskrit, material advancement is called Anartha, unwanted things, unwanted. Actually, this is so. This is a fact. Material advancement is Anartha. It is not required. So, Prabhupada gives an example that in the present context of material advancement, one uses lipstick at a cost of 50 cents and there are so many unwanted things which are all products of material conception of life. So many material possessions people have, but that makes them only entangled, and subsequently, they have to face so many unwanted miseries. Everybody understands miseries are unwanted, but that's a result of possessing so many material things which are actually Anartha. So, Prabhupada's instruction is give up this business of material advancement and take to Krishna consciousness under the guidance of pure devotees.

The very conception of the personality of Godhead as a human being is misleading. Krishna is not a human being. Krishna is the Supreme Unlimited Lord, full of all good qualities. He is absolute. He is all good. Every living being is his part and parcel and therefore every living being is dear to him as the part and parcel living being. His pastimes in this material world especially appear to be exactly like a human being's activities, but actually they are transcendental. They are without any tinge of material contamination because Krishna does not come in contact with material nature. The material modes are not able to influence Krishna. In other words, they are all inconceivable to the limited thinking power of the human being. What is the reality? We cannot conceive of a personality who is simultaneously unborn and still takes birth. He is active, yet he has nothing to do. So we cannot conceive what kind of a personality is that. Even though the Supreme Lord is all-pervading Supersoul of all existence, still he appears in the form of a boar among animals, in the form of a human being among inhuman society as Rama, Krishna, etc. Or he appears in the form of a rishi like Narayana Rishi, or he appears in the form of an aquatic like a fish, Matsyavatara. Still, Kunti is saying he is unborn. Even the scriptures declare Aja. In Bhagavad Gita, Krishna says Ajo Pisannabhya Yatma. He is Aja, he is unborn. And Name Parthasthi Kartavyam Trishulokeshu Kinchana. Krishna says in Bhagavad Gita. Here also it is said, there is nothing to do. And even in the Vedas, Natasyakaryam Karanam Javidhyate. then we can get some understanding about Krishna's personality as inconceivable for our tiny brain. Everything is possible for him because everything is reconciled in his personality. ### Vishwaroopa (universal form) description, greatness of Krishna, Krishna is greater than the greatest and smaller than the smallest

We have to hear devotees like Venkati. Now, there is a description of Krishna's Viratrupa or Vishwarupa, one form of the Lord. The external body of Krishna as described in the description given of the Viratrupa or Vishwarupa. The hills and mountains are described as the bones of the Lord. So many hills are there. So many mountains are there. They are all described as the bones of the Virat Purusha. The great oceans have been described as the different holes in the Lord's universal body. The planet Brahmaloka has been described as the upper portion of his skull. Like this, the universal form has been described in so many ways. But then, the earth and the sky are intended to be the upper portion, because they are the set of the earth. The certain part of the earth and the sky is where the earth is. This is the only thing about which the universe is. Let us veer from the present state. In Brahma's view, the matter of the universe is to have run—what makes the universe and God's existence both greater than the matter of the universe. Now, it is said here, Brahma Shankar Prabhupada, there are people who can simply think of God as being great, but they do not know how great he is. They are thinking in terms of what they consider as great. So then they are misguided. So, then they are misled to believe some Devatas as God or some other powerful person they think is God. So, therefore, the Vishwaroopa description of the Lord, Supreme Lord is given in the scriptures that if you think of greatness of the Supreme Lord, think of the hills and mountains as the bones of the universal form. So, how many hills are there? How many mountains are there? You cannot count. So, this form is the universal form is very, very, very, very huge. Nobody can see. Arjuna was given special eyes to see that universal form. Otherwise, nobody can see this form of the Supreme Lord. So, Krishna is simultaneously greater than the greatest, Mahato Mahiyan, and he is smaller than the smallest, Anoranyan. That is Krishna's wonderful characteristic. Simultaneously, he is greater than the greatest and smaller than the smallest. So, the Vishwaroopa is the biggest form of anyone in this entire universe, and the form of the Supersoul who has entered into every atom is much, much smaller than the atom. That form of the Lord is actually the Lord being smaller than the smallest, Anoranyan. So, this is also greatness of the Lord. Simultaneously, he is present as greater than the greatest and smaller than the smallest.

So Kunti Devi is explaining how one can end this repetition of birth and death. Of course, most people do not know that the real fundamental problem of material existence is this repetition of birth and death. It's called samsara or bhava. So this accepting this material body, while we are actually not got anything to do with matter, we are pure spirit and we have our spiritual body, we have our spiritual heart, we have our home, the abode of Krishna, Krishnaloka, but foolishly we give up that spiritual home and we desire independent enjoyment, we desire to lord over material nature and therefore we are forced to take this material body which is called birth and we cannot remain in this material body permanently, we have to quit this material body by force, that's called death and after death if we still have desire for lording over or we have desire for material enjoyment, independent enjoyment then we have to continue to accept another body and that's another birth. So jatasyahi dhruva mṛtyu dhruvam janma mṛtasyaca Krishna explains this in the Bhagavad Gita, for one who has taken his birth in this material world death is certain and after death if one is not liberated at the time of death then one has to take birth again, cannot avoid. So Kunti Devi is now telling who can actually stop this repetition of birth and death, those who continuously hear, chant, and repeat the transcendental activities of Krishna or even if they don't do it they simply take pleasure in somebody else who is doing that, such persons are able to have darshan of Krishna's lotus feet by which they are very easily able to conquer this material existence, they are able to stop the repetition of birth and death.

Now the supreme lord Krishna also wanted that at the last stage of his material existence, the great warrior Bhishma Deva should see Krishna personally at the time of his quitting the body, and Bhishma should also see his beloved grandchildren, the Pandavas, and thus pass away very peacefully, because Bhishma Deva was not at all satisfied to fight against the Pandavas, because he knew Pandavas cause is just. So Prabhupada explains the reason why Bhishma Deva was constrained to fight on the side of the Kauravas. The reason is that Kshatriyas are very stern people, and therefore Bhishma Deva, he was obliged to take the side of Duryodhana. Why was he obliged to take the side of Duryodhana? Because Bhishma was maintained at the expense of Duryodhana.

So what is the use of marrying my daughter to this emperor? So he refused, this fisherman refused Shantanu. Shantanu said okay. But when Bhishma found out that my father has been refused, he went to the fisherman and said, what is the reason you are refusing to marry your daughter to my father? So then the fisherman explained. Bhishma said, I forsake the claim to the throne. The son born of your daughter will be the next emperor. Then Bhishma thought that the fisherman will accept. The fisherman said okay, the son born of my daughter will be the emperor, but after that son, your son will claim the throne of the whole world, because you are forsaking, but he may not forsake. So then Bhishma agreed to remain a brahmachari, not to marry, and that way Shantanu was able to marry that fisherman's daughter Satyavati. Srila Prabhupada says, King Yudhishthira, though he was not expected to become aggrieved like a common man, became deluded by worldly affection by the will of the Supreme Lord Krishna, just as Arjuna was apparently deluded on the battlefield of Kurukshetra before the war began, again by the arrangement of Krishna only. Both Yudhishthira and Arjuna are pure devotees. All the five Pandavas are pure devotees. So there is no question of them becoming deluded by Maya. Krishna arranged that Yudhishthira should become overwhelmed by worldly affection for the loss of so many people in this battle. You have heard this many times in the Bhagavad Gita and all the scriptures, it is explained, we are spirit soul, we are not the body, we are not the mind. Both the gross body and the subtle body are coverings for the real person within the body, that is the spirit soul. The common man thinks of violence and non-violence in terms of the body, but that is a kind of delusion. Just considering the body alone is a big mistake. Everyone is duty bound according to one's occupation. Occupational duties, swadharma or varnashrama dharma. A kshatriya is bound to fight for the right cause regardless of the opposite party. In this case, Yudhishthira was fighting against his own cousins, the Kauravas. But for the right cause, a kshatriya should not refuse to fight. That is what Krishna explains in the Bhagavad Gita to Arjuna also. In discharge of duty, one should not be disturbed by annihilation of the material body, which is only an external dress of the living soul. Similarly, the body itself, the physical body is simply an external covering of the spirit soul. And when it is worn out, then one discards that. That is what is called death, discarding this body and accept a new body. All this was perfectly known to Yudhishthira Maharaj. But by the will of the Supreme Lord Krishna, he became just like a common man, because there was another great idea behind this delusion.

Krishna had another plan, why Yudhishthira should become deluded. What is that great idea? King Yudhishthira would be instructed by Bhishma, as Arjuna was instructed by Lord Krishna himself. This body, which is ultimately meant for others, has killed many many phalanxes of men. Phalanx means akshauhini in Sanskrit. Then the purport should be appropriate to explain what is the count of a phalanx or akshauhini division. A solid phalanx of 21,870 chariots, 21,870 elephants, 109,650 infantry, and 65,600 cavalry is called an akshauhini. Chariots here mean chariot fighters. And elephants means on elephant back there are powerful warriors who fight from elephant back. And infantry means those on foot, soldiers on foot. And cavalry means those who are on horseback, fighters on horseback. So, these four kinds of fighters are there in a battle in the Vedic times, in the Vedic culture. So, akshauhini division is very very big. 21,000 and odd chariots, 21,000 and odd elephants, 109,000 infantry, and 65,000 odd cavalry. So many. And like this how many divisions were there totally on the battlefield of Kurukshetra? 11 on the Kaurava side. 11 akshauhini divisions on the Kaurava side, and 7 akshauhini divisions on the Pandava side. Totally 18 akshauhini divisions were fighting in this battle of Kurukshetra.

Sometimes people wonder, what is the purpose of this creation? The purpose of this creation is to give a chance to the conditioned souls. All of us are called conditioned souls. We are conditioned by this material nature. We develop desires to enjoy, thinking that we are this body, we belong to this world. And our life continues birth after birth after birth because we have so many varieties of desires for enjoying. But actually Krishna's purpose is different. Krishna wants us to realize we don't belong here because we are spirit, soul, we are not the body. And as spiritual beings, we can never be really satisfied and happy by material pleasures, by material enjoyment, by material lordship. We can never be satisfied or happy. So Krishna wants us to realize this. And for this purpose, Krishna has created this world in such a way that in the human form of life, we have developed intelligence. And if we are guided on the spiritual path of emancipation, of liberation from material bondage, then very easily we are able to understand and act appropriately under proper guidance and become completely free from all entanglements and go back to our original position in the spiritual world to enjoy eternal life of bliss and knowledge. This is the whole plan of the Supreme Personality of Godhead. This is the purpose of creation: to liberate all the living beings, especially the human beings. And a proper Kshatriya ruling the human beings, ruling this world and particularly guiding the human beings on this path of liberation. It is possible that everyone can be liberated if they are guided by a king like Yudhishthira.

So, Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport, Ashwamedha Yajnas or Gomeda Yajnas, sacrifices in which a horse or a bull is sacrificed, were not, of course, for the purpose of killing the animals. This is a very important point to be understood here. A sacrifice recommended in the scriptures is never meant for killing animals. Even though, actually, in such a sacrifice, a horse or a bull is killed, it is not meant for killing. How do we understand this? So, Lord Chaitanya explains that such animals sacrificed on the altar of Yajna were rejuvenated and a new life was given to them. See, in all such sacrifices, even though there is a horse or a bull, that killed horse or bull is rejuvenated by giving it new life. In some cases, the soul in the animal's body is promoted immediately to the human form of life. It was just to prove the efficacy of the hymns of the Vedas. In the Vedas, in the Vedic sacrifice, there are four kinds of priests. There is the priest who chants the mantras, and the mantra chanting should have the power, the purity of the brahmana, who has perfected his mantra chanting, because of which the chanting will be effective. And in case the brahmana who is chanting the mantras is unable to revive an animal, because his chanting is not sufficiently powerful, then there is a referee priest who actually takes over and actually he chants the mantras to revive the animal, the animal which is sacrificed, and he also chants for the sake of the sacrifice. So, the whole process is to give new life to an animal, and for the testing of the chanting of the mantra, such an act is done.

### Varnashrama Dharma, Social Order, Liberation, Worship of Vishnu
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/YfW_uuY71Z8?t=451
**Verse References:** BG 4.13
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Society can be perfectly organised in that way."
**Summary:** The speaker discusses the varnashrama dharma, explaining that Krishna created the four divisions of society based on qualities and work, and that the goal is ultimate liberation through performance of one's duty and worship of Vishnu.

In the fourth chapter of Bhagavad Gita, Krishna says, chaaturvarnyam maya-srishtam guna-karma-vibhaga-saha. He says, it is I who have created these four divisions of social orders in human society: chaaturvarnyam brahmana-kshatriya-vaisa-shudra. Society can be perfectly organised in that way: the intellectuals, the administrators, the business class, the productive class, that is the business class, and the labourers. And different people have different skills, different qualities. They are born under different influences of the gunas. Accordingly, they can be engaged properly in some livelihood, means of livelihood. But everybody is entitled, eligible for ultimate liberation in the human form of life. And that's what the whole varnashrama dharma is about: how to worship Vishnu by performance of your duty in such a way that you will actually be ultimately liberated from material bondage.

As there is control by time all over the planets, you see total control by kala. Kala is a representative of the supreme lord in this material world. Srila Vishwanath Chakraborty Thakur is another Acharya. He is a previous Acharya. In the Gaudiya Vaishnava Sampradaya, he is one of the great Acharyas of the modern age. He explains, what does he explain? That Anubhava or the glory of the Lord is first appreciated by the devotee in ecstasy, manifesting the symptoms of perspiring, trembling, weeping, bodily eruptions, etc., which are further enhanced by steady understanding of the glories of the Lord. So, this is a little technical thing. Let me explain this. As we progress in devotional service, more and more revelation about Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, happens within our heart, within our consciousness. Just like in the beginning, we just are told, chant Hare Krishna, and you hear about Krishna from the Bhagavad Gita, from the Bhagavad, through the medium of the pure devotees or their representatives, who repeat what the pure devotees are explaining. So, this practice of Sadhana Bhakti gradually leads to a better understanding of Krishna as the transcendental personality. Transcendental personality means he is not like one of us. He is not like... He is not like an ordinary, a created being. He is not a created being. He is the original Lord. He never accepts a material body. He never accepts a material body. He never has a material body. He doesn't require a material body. He has a transcendental form. He has the transcendental supreme form. So, he comes and incarnates in that same form. So, these things we will understand gradually as we practice devotional service, by chanting, hearing, reading, doing some practical service, worshipping the Deity, etc. All these different ways of rendering service to Krishna, if we engage in those different activities, gradually our heart becomes cleansed of misgivings, of misconceptions, of ignorance, and we become enlightened, gradually. It takes time. So, as the enlightenment... As the enlightenment increases, as the knowledge about Krishna becomes more and more revealed in the heart, we come to a stage called bhava. Bhava is the stage where we are able to understand the absolute nature of Krishna. He is non-different from his name, from his quality, from his activity, from his paraphernalia, from his... From his code, from his form, from his deity, from his descriptions in the Bhagavatam, he is non-different. All are identical, absolute, personality of Godhead.

### Anubhava, Ecstasy, Ashtasatvika Vikara, Krishna-Yashoda Relationship
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/ZShSbvHtcKM?t=537
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Anubhava is appreciated by the devotee in ecstasy."
**Summary:** The lecture elaborates on anubhava, a subdivision of bhava, characterized by ecstasy and physical symptoms like perspiring and trembling, using the example of Yashoda binding Krishna with a rope.

In that bhava, there are different sub-divisions, one of which is explained here as anubhava. Anubhava is appreciated by the devotee in ecstasy. Ecstasy means bhava. Ecstasy means bhava. Ecstasy means bhava. So, in the stage of bhava, there is ecstasy, and that ecstasy means one is able to experience extreme joy, spiritual joy, through symptoms like perspiring, trembling, weeping, bodily eruptions, etc. There are eight such symptoms called ashtasatvika vikara. There is a change in the body. The body cannot contain the spiritual transformation. There is a transcendental joy called ecstasy. So, therefore, there are changes in the body. And these are all symptoms which are manifest in this body, which confirms that the devotee has advanced to the stage of being able to experience the ecstasy because of coming to the stage of bhava, advancing to the stage of bhava. Now, these symptoms of bhava, like perspiring, trembling, weeping, etc., are further enhanced by steady understanding of the glories of the Lord. There is an initial understanding of the glories. We begin to understand the glories of the Lord. And then after that the devotional service continues and the understanding becomes steady. It is not an effect that is experienced for a little time and then the effect is gone. No, it becomes steady, it becomes continuous. Such different understandings of bhava are exchanged between Yashoda and the Lord as a small child, the son of mother Yashoda. The Lord binding Krishna, Yashoda binding Krishna with the rope, Damodar Leela and in the chariot driving by the Lord in the exchange of love with Arjuna. These are not ordinary activities.

### Krishna-Arjuna Relationship, Subordination, Love, Glories of the Lord
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/ZShSbvHtcKM?t=713
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The glories of the Lord which are exhibited in this being subordinated before his devotees is another feature of the glories of the Lord."
**Summary:** The speaker discusses Krishna's relationship with Arjuna, highlighting how Krishna assumes a subordinate position as Arjuna's chariot driver out of love, showcasing another aspect of His glories.

Or Krishna driving the chariot of Arjuna, Partha Sarathi on the battlefield of Kurukshetra. This is also an exchange of love between the Lord and his pure devotee Arjuna. Krishna has no need to do anything. Bhati is engaged in activities and relationship with his devotees out of love for them. And the devotees also, they are engaged in serving Krishna in their relationship with Krishna in different ways. So, in some of these exchanges of love, the Lord assumes an equal position or a subordinate position. In the case of Arjuna, normally Arjuna and Krishna as friends are on an equal platform. But, when Krishna agreed to become the chariot driver of Arjuna, then Krishna assumed the subordinate position. Arjuna is ordering Krishna. In the first chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, this statement is there by Arjuna to Krishna: "Kindly take my chariot between the two armies who are assembled for fighting in the battlefield of Kurukshetra." Arjuna is ordering Krishna. Now, the special feature of such an exchange is explained here by Prabhupāda. The glories of the Lord which are exhibited in this being subordinated before his devotees is another feature of the glories of the Lord. You see, when the Lord agrees to become subordinate of Krishna, he agrees to become subordinated by the devotees because he is the Supreme Lord. He is always the Lord. He is always the Master in all circumstances. But, he agrees to become subordinate in the exchange of love. So, it is another feature of the glories of the Lord. It is the glory of the Supreme Lord. Even though he is unconditionally always the Supreme Lord, he agrees to become subordinate to his devotees out of love for the devotees.

The devotees are always free from material miseries even in the material world. But, apparently they sometimes become distressed. But, that is due to the Lord putting them in difficulty to exchange transcendental bhava.

### Krishna's energies, Paramatma, Guidance, Devotional service
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/RqD7dz64DxI?t=607
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Krishna is already the chariot driver and counsel of every living being."
**Summary:** The speaker explains how Krishna is present everywhere through his energies and as the Paramatma, guiding everyone from within, and that his role as Arjuna's chariot driver was due to Arjuna's devotional service.

The sun is identified with every inch of the sun rays. The sun is somewhere in the spiritual sky, millions of miles away from the earth, but the sunshine is coming to the earth and providing heat and light and energy and sustaining life on this planet. So that sunshine is, in one sense, not different from the Sun. It is the energy of the Sun, and we can identify the Sun as full of this energy, which we call sunshine, sun rays. Similarly, the Lord is distributed by his different energies. The Lord is present by virtue of his being present as energy, his own energy spread everywhere. He is Paramatma, the Supersoul, present in everything that is present in the universe and in the universe and in the universe, and everyone has a supreme guidance. Not only Krishna's energies are spread everywhere in this material world as a material energy, he has also entered into everyone's heart, every living being's heart, as the Supersoul, as the Paramatma. That is another form of Krishna, who is an expansion of Krishna, who has entered into everybody's heart, and he is giving guidance to every living heart, and he is giving guidance to every living being from within the heart. Therefore, Krishna is already the chariot driver and counsel of every living being, Sarathi. He is not just guiding Arjuna alone; he is guiding everyone as the Paramatma in their heart. So, therefore, Prabhupada is explaining how, when Krishna exhibits himself as chariot driver of Arjuna, there is no change in his exalted position. He is already seated in Arjuna's heart as the Paramatma. He is guiding Arjuna, so externally when he apparently becomes the chariot driver of Arjuna and guides Arjuna while driving his chariot, there's no change in his position. So it is only because of the devotional service that Arjuna wants to render to Krishna.

### Krishna's absolute nature, Superior and inferior positions, Loving reciprocation, Devotee relationship
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/RqD7dz64DxI?t=760
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Krishna being absolute there is no difference between his superior position and inferior position in his relationship with his devotees he remains always the supreme lord"
**Summary:** The speaker discusses the absolute nature of Krishna, explaining that there is no difference between his superior and inferior positions, and that all his actions are loving reciprocations with his devotees.

Otherwise, to give guidance to Arjuna, Krishna is already in Arjuna's heart. What is the need for Krishna to come externally, appear as the chariot driver of Arjuna? There is no need. Then Prabhupada explains he does that for the sake of teaching the others, not Arjuna. For the sake of teaching others, he speaks the Bhagavad-Gita to Arjuna. Even though he is a chariot driver of Arjuna, he is the Lord, and he speaks Bhagavad-Gita, and through Arjuna, he is instructing and educating the whole world. So this is the absolute nature of Krishna. For Krishna, there is nothing superior and inferior action. When he is instructing Arjuna as the spiritual master of Arjuna, he is in apparently in a superior position. Arjuna is submitting, surrendering, and Arjuna is inquiring from Krishna, "Kindly guide me, kindly instruct me, kindly enlighten me," and Krishna is instructing, enlightening Arjuna, so superior position. When Arjuna is ordering, "Take my chariot between the two armies," Krishna is in an inferior position apparently, but actually, it is explained Krishna being absolute, there is no difference between his superior position and inferior position. In his relationship with his devotees, he remains always the supreme Lord. He may assume any—He may do any activity, inferior or superior according to our calculation, but as far as Krishna is concerned, it is simply his loving reciprocation with his devotees, whether it is Mother Yashoda, whether it is Radharani, whether it is Arjuna, whether it is any devotee, even Bhishma. We will hear how Bhishma is praying to Krishna, "Kindly be present before me at the time of my death, quitting the body."

### Dependence on Krishna, illusory energy, limitations of material affection
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/H5XIV92y_1M?t=155
**Verse References:** BG 9.29
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "This is the position of every one of us, that we have no other protector other than Krishna."
**Summary:** The speaker elaborates on the idea that true protection comes only from Krishna, as material affection is limited by the illusory energy and the modes of material nature.

Unflinching servitor, the word used is Ekanta Bhakteshu. Ekanta Bhakta. In the purport, Srila Prabhupada explains, The Supreme Lord, the Absolute Personality of Godhead, Sri Krishna, although equal to everyone, is still more inclined to his unflinching devotee who is completely surrendered and knows no one else as his protector and master. This is the position of every one of us, that we have no other protector other than Krishna. Why do I say that? Because, even though in the material world we have our well-wishers, our parents, or our near and dear family members, who actually, within the heart, they have a sense of affection. For us, each one of us has got somebody who is very dear to us. Even then, all this affection is on the platform of the illusory energy. This truth is not known to most people in this world. I don't mean to say that people make a show of being affectionate while they don't have any affection in the heart. I don't mean that. What I mean is, each one of us, we are in ignorance about our real self. We are completely under the clutches of the three gunas, three modes of material nature. So, we are not able to express our affection when our consciousness gets bewildered by the influence of the external energy. So, even though I want to give protection to somebody whom I consider as my very, very, very dear relative or friend, still, because I myself am a person who is a person, I am not able to express my affection. Not in a secure position, how can I give protection to somebody else when my own position is very, very insecure? So therefore, who is the person who can really give everyone real protection, who is above the three gunas, who's transcendental to the modes of material nature? So that is explained by Prabhupada.

### Unflinching devotion, Krishna's protection, relationship of the soul, Bhishma's example
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/H5XIV92y_1M?t=790
**Verse References:** —

**Summary:** The speaker reiterates that Krishna's appearance at Bhishma's deathbed is due to his unflinching devotion and emphasizes that the relationship between the soul and the Supreme Soul is eternal and not based on bodily connections.

The appearance of Lord Krishna at the deathbed of Bhishma ji is due to his being an unflinching devotee of the Lord. So when somebody is a pure devotee under all circumstances, unfailing in all circumstances, then the Supreme Lord protects such a devotee always, especially when the devotee has to quit the body at the time of death. That is a critical moment in one's life. Arjuna had some bodily relation with Krishna because the Lord happened to be his maternal cousin. But he did not have any physical relation with Krishna. But Bhishma had no such bodily relation. When Krishna helps the Pandavas, somebody may think that, Oh, because Krishna is related to the Pandavas through some bodily relationship. Actually, there is no bodily relationship between Krishna and anybody. Krishna does not have a material body. So where is the question of bodily relationship? But even if for the sake of his Leela, he appears as the son of Devaki or Vasudeva. Vasudeva and Kunti are having that blood relationship. Vasudeva is the brother of Kunti. So Kunti's sons, the Pandavas, and Vasudeva's son Krishna, through such relationships between Vasudeva and Kunti, they are related as maternal cousins. But what about Bhishma? Bhishma has no such bodily relationship. So therefore, Prabhupada says, in the case of Bhishma, the cause of attraction was due to the intimate relation of the soul. So how is it that Krishna appeared in front of Bhishma? And Bhishma is acknowledging that very kindly the Supreme Lord has appeared when I am about to quit the body. It is because of the relationship of the soul. And that relation is eternal. It is never based on any bodily connections. It is a relationship between the soul with the Supreme Soul.

So, they are dependent on bhikṣa. They beg or live by whatever is available easily in nature. So, the Grahasthas have to do this charity, giving dāna to whom? To Brahmachārīs, to the Vānaprasthas, and Sannyāsas. All three are engaged in spiritual activities exclusively. So, charity is to be given to somebody exclusively devoted to spiritual activities. Charity is not to be given to somebody who is poor, somebody who is handicapped. No, that is not charity. That's not dāna. That is different. What is that called? That's called daya. See, try to understand the difference between dāna and daya. Prabhupāda explains this elsewhere. Daya means to show compassion to somebody who is less privileged, who is, let's say, a handicapped person, who is not able to do any work to earn money. You may support such a person by giving some help, but that is not dāna. That is called daya. It's compassion. A doctor may give free treatment to some poor person who is sick or diseased. That is called daya. That is not dāna.

In the purport, Srila Prabhupada explains, When Shri Krishna by his own internal pleasure appears on earth, he does so by the agency of his internal potency. What is the meaning of this statement? Krishna has got three kinds of energies. Krishna is the supreme person, he has got energies which are serving him, which are working for him. So everything he does through the agency of his energy. He personally has nothing to do because his energies carry out whatever he wants to do according to his will. Simply he has to decide or will to do something and it is carried out perfectly. These three categories of energies are his internal potency, his external potency and his marginal potency. Internal potency is a spiritual energy and it is meant for Krishna's own purposes exclusively. The external potency is the material energy meant for the conditioned souls. And the marginal potency consists of the living beings, innumerable, countless living beings, some of whom are in the material world, the conditioned souls. Majority of the living beings belonging to the marginal potency are in the spiritual world as pure devotees of Krishna. So, some very, very small number compared to the number of living beings who are pure devotees in the spiritual world, the number of living beings in this material world as conditioned souls are very small number.

This is the necessity of the illusory energy acting on the conditioned souls. So, Krishna never comes in contact with the illusory energy or the material energy. The meaning of this verse is, let my mind be fixed upon Lord Sri Krishna, whose motions and smiles of love attracted the damsels of Raja Dharma, the Gopis. The damsels imitated the characteristic movements of the Lord after his disappearance from the Rasa dance. This is yet another precept. This is the same prayer offered by Bhishma Deva to Lord Krishna. Bhishma is fixing his mind upon Lord Sri Krishna and remembering the different pastimes of Krishna. Smaranam, remembering the pastimes of Krishna, remembering the form of Krishna, remembering the name of Krishna, remembering the qualities of Krishna. This is bhakti. This is the practice of bhakti. Here, specifically, Bhishma Deva is remembering Krishna's pastimes with his topmost devotees, the Gopis of Vrindavan. So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada explains what is the characteristic of the Gopis' devotion to Krishna. It is explained by Srila Prabhupada in the purport, By intense ecstasy in loving service, the damsels of Vraja Bhumi, that is the Gopis, attained qualitative oneness with the Lord by dancing with him on an equal level, by embracing him in nuptial love, by smiling at him, by looking at him in joke, and by looking at him with a loving attitude. The Gopis are in a relationship with Krishna in conjugal love. Conjugal love means love between opposite genders. Actually, Krishna is the only male, and everyone else is female. Krishna is the only Purusha, everyone else is Prakriti. So, this love between Krishna and the devotees is natural, is our constitutional position. So, among the devotees of Krishna, the topmost devotees are the Gopis. Now, Srila Prabhupada says, the relation of the Lord with Arjuna is undoubtedly praiseworthy for devotees like Bhishma Deva, because Arjuna's friendship with the Lord was very, very intimate friendship. It was transcendental relationship, not material friendship. But, the relation of the Gopis with the Lord is still more praiseworthy because of their still more purified loving service. Now, how is Gopis' devotional service more purified? To understand that, Srila Prabhupada explains, that according to Lord Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, ramyakachit upasana vrajavadhu vargena yakalpita. The meaning of this is, this is what Chaitanya Mahaprabhu says about the Gopis' devotional service rendered to Lord Krishna. There is no better method of worship than the system invented by the Gopis. Worship of Krishna. The best method of worship is that which was performed by the Gopis of Vrindavan. So, the Gopis' invention of worshipping Krishna was to remain always Krishna conscious without any material profit. That is the super excellence of the Gopis. Super excellent devotional service. They never expected any return from Krishna. That was not their business. Their attitude was not like, Krishna, we have done so much for you. Can you give us some benediction, Krishna? No. They never expected any benediction from Krishna. Though Krishna is the Supreme Lord, who is the only giver of all kinds of benedictions, but the Gopis, they never expected any benediction from Krishna. Gopis' attitude was that you take whatever you like from us, but we do not ask anything in exchange, in return. Nothing. We want nothing. They simply want to please Krishna. That's all. They only want to see Krishna happy. That's all. We have got everything to give you, and we have no need to ask you anything at all.

**Summary:** The speaker explains the historical context of the Rajasuya Yajna, including the tradition of the challenge horse and Yudhishthira's acceptance as emperor.

Therefore, he performed this Rajasuya Yajna. So it is explained by Sri Lakshmi that after gaining victory in the battle of Kurukshetra, Maharaj Yudhishthira, the emperor of the world, performed a Rajasuya sacrificial ceremony. The emperor in those days, upon his ascendance to the throne, would send a challenge horse all over the world to declare his supremacy, and any ruling prince or king was at liberty to accept the challenge and express his tacit willingness either to obey or to disobey the supremacy of the particular king of the world. The world was ruled in different provinces by different kings, but one king was the emperor of the whole world. Generally, the king whose capital was Hastinapura, at least 5000 years back, that was the system. So one who accepted the challenge of the emperor, whichever king, king of a smaller province, he had to fight with the emperor and establish his own supremacy by victory. The defeated challenger would have to sacrifice his life, making a place for another king or ruler. This was the system. So Maharaj Yudhishthira also dispatched such challenging horses all over the world, and every ruling prince and king all over the world accepted Maharaj Yudhishthira's leadership as the emperor of the world.

Hare Krishna, Hare Krishna, Krishna Krishna, Hare Hare, Hare Rama, Hare Rama, Rama Rama, Hare Hare, Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya, Narayanam Namaskritya, Naram Chai Vanarottamam, Devim Sarasvatim Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Rayet. Suta Uvacha Krishna Evam Bhagavati Manovag Drishti Vritti Bhihi Atmani Atmanam Aveshya So Anta Shvasa Uparamat. The meaning of this verse is: Suta Goswami said, "Thus Bhishma Deva merged himself in the Supersoul, Lord Sri Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, with his mind, speech, sight and actions, and thus he became silent and his breathing stilled." So this is the verse that is describing Bhishma Deva has quit his body in Krishna consciousness, because his mind, his speech, his sight and actions are all completely absorbed in Krishna. So Srila Prabhupada says in the purport, "The stage attained by Bhishma Deva while quitting his material body is called Nirvikalpa Samadhi." This is a technical term. What is the meaning of this term Nirvikalpa Samadhi? That is also explained by Srila Prabhupada. Nirvikalpa Samadhi, it is called Nirvikalpa Samadhi because he, that is Bhishma Deva, merged himself into thinking of the Lord and his mind into remembering, remembering his different activities. He chanted the glories of the Lord, that is his speech. And by his sight, he began to see the Lord personally present before him. And thus, all his activities became concentrated upon the Lord without deviation. Samadhi means total absorption. Total absorption of the mind, of the thinking, that is the mind, activity of the mind, the speech, and the sight, and the very self. So, thinking, remembering, glorifying, and seeing, in all these ways, Bhishma was totally absorbed in thought of Krishna. This is the highest stage of perfection, this total absorption, and it is possible for everyone to attain this stage by practice of devotional service. So here, Prabhupada is teaching us that there is the highest perfectional stage to be attained in the practice of devotional service. Devotional service means practicing, focusing our attention on Krishna. Krishna means the Supreme Personality of Godhead. We are focusing our attention on Krishna. He has so many different features. So every possible way if we can absorb our self in thought of Krishna, in thinking of Krishna, in glorifying Krishna, in hearing about Krishna, in seeing Krishna's form either as the Deity or as the personally Krishna is present in the case of Bhishma. He is personally present. So Bhishma is directly seeing Krishna before quitting his body and the beautiful form. ### Devotional Service, Nine Principles of Bhakti, Service Attitude
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Myj43RT1ytI?t=331

**Summary:** This segment details the nine principles of devotional service (Shravanam, Kirtanam, Smaranam, etc.) as outlined in the Bhagavatam, emphasizing that bhakti involves active service with a loving attitude towards Krishna, and that any of these practices can lead to perfection.

So this is the highest perfection to be attained and it is possible for anyone provided one practices devotional service. Now devotional service itself, how is it performed? So Srila Prabhupada says based on the explanation in the seventh canto of the Bhagavatam. The devotional service of the Lord Krishna consists of nine principles of service activities. Devotional service is not something idle, simply sitting and doing nothing. No. Devotional service, Bhakti, means devotional service. So it consists of service activities, activities rendered while having a service attitude. I want to serve Krishna to please him. I want to serve Krishna in a loving attitude. And these nine principles of service activities are described in the Bhagavatam seventh canto as: Number one, hearing, hearing about Krishna, Shravanam. Number two, chanting, Kirtanam. Number three, remembering, remembering in Sanskrit it is called Smaranam. Number four, serving the lotus feet of Krishna, Padashevanam. Number five, worshipping, Archanam, Deity worship, specifically Deity worship. Number six, praying, Vandanam, offering prayers, just like Bhishma did. He was remembering Krishna's pastimes. He was praying, offering prayers. He was chanting the glories of Krishna, and like that he was engaged in all possible ways in service activities before quitting his body, totally absorbed in that. So number seven, executing the orders, it's called Dasyam. A servant is specially meant for simply carrying out the orders of the master, just like Hanuman. Whatever Rama ordered, Hanuman simply carried out that order. So that is Dasyam. Then eighth one of the list of nine service activities, eighth one is fraternizing, Sakhyam, acting as a rendering service rather, as a friend of the Lord, friend of Lord Krishna, just like Arjuna, rendering service as a friend of Krishna. And the final one, ninth one, fully surrendering, Atma Nivedanam, total self surrender. Bali Maharaj. Each one of these, we have an ideal described in the Bhagavatam. Any one of them, any one of the nine or all of them are equally competent to award the desired result. That is the highest perfection of total absorption of oneself in the Supreme Lord Krishna, but they require to be practiced persistently

### Analogy, Service to Krishna, Material Activities, Uselessness
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/sGLdAzVMr5U?t=392
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** analogy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "So, we as spirit soul, tiny, tiny, tiny spirit soul, we are totally useless when we are separate from Kṛṣṇa."
**Summary:** Using the analogy of a machine and its parts, the speaker explains that a spirit soul separated from Krishna is useless, and that material activities are also useless because they are not in service to Krishna.

This is an example being given by Prabhupāda to help us understand how we are connected with the Lord. Any part of the machine removed from the whole is no longer important. You can understand this point. Let's say there is a small screw which is holding some particular item in the entire machine, huge machine, several parts. Now that screw, if it falls off, what is the value of this screw? But as long as it is connected with the machine, it is very, very important. It is doing a very specific function and it is very important. So, any part of the machine removed from the whole is no longer important. So, we as spirit soul, tiny, tiny, tiny spirit soul, we are totally useless when we are separate from Kṛṣṇa. Of course, we cannot be separated, inseparable. But if we want to separate or we want to try to separate, then our life is useless. Similarly, any part and parcel of the Absolute detached from the service of the Lord is useless. Now, material activity means so many activities we perform which is not service of the Lord. That is useless. All material activities are useless because they are not of the nature of service of the Supreme Lord Krishna.

**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Bhishma Deva was the most affectionate grandfather of the Pandavas, and caretaker of the widow daughter-in-law Kunti Devi."
**Summary:** The lecture begins with an explanation of the verse, focusing on Yudhishthira's grief after Bhishma Deva's death and then delves into the historical context of Dhritarashtra's ambition and the Pandavas' rightful claim to the throne.

In this session we will be discussing from the 46th verse of the 9th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. तस्य निर्हरणादीनि संपरे तस्य भार्गव युदिष्ठिरक कारयित्वा मुहूर्तं दुख्यितो भवत। The meaning of this verse is, O descendant of Bhrigu, शवनका, after performing funeral rituals for the dead body of Bhishma Deva, Maharaj Yudhishthira was momentarily overtaken with grief. So, Suta Goswami speaking this verse, he is addressing Shavunaka Rishi, the sages headed by Shavunaka Rishi. Shavunaka Rishi is addressed as Bhargava, descendant of Bhrigu Rishi or Bhrigu Muni. He is coming in the dynasty of Bhrigu Rishi, Bhrigu Vamsha. So, the description is being given here that Yudhishthira, after Bhishma Deva passed away, he quit his body at the most auspicious moment, and more importantly, he quit his body in the presence of Lord Sri Krishna, and he quit his body while his mind was completely absorbed in thought, in remembrance of Krishna. So, perfect way of quitting the body, ideal for all the devotees, for everyone. So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada explains, Bhishma Deva was not only a great family head of Maharaj Yudhishthira, but also he was a great philosopher and friend to him, his brothers and his mother, the entire Pandavas. Kunti is the name of a family, the five Pandavas brothers, and their mother Kunti, Kunti Devi. Since Maharaj Pandu, the father of the five brothers headed by Maharaj Yudhishthira, had died, Bhishma Deva was the most affectionate grandfather of the Pandavas, and caretaker of the widow daughter-in-law Kunti Devi. Bhishma Deva's granddaughter was the daughter of Lord Pundit, Krishna's daughter, Bhishmadeva's brother was Vichitravirya. Vichitravirya's son was Pandu. So, Bhishmadeva's daughter-in-law or Vichitravirya's daughter-in-law was Kuntidevi. In that way, it is being described here, Bhishmadeva's relationship with Kuntidevi. Although Maharaj Dhritarashtra, the elder uncle of Maharaj Yudhishthira, was there to look after them, his affection, that is Dhritarashtra's affection, was more on the side of his hundred sons, headed by Duryodhana. Dhritarashtra was very much unhappy about the fact that Dhritarashtra himself could not ascend the throne of the emperor of the entire world, the throne of Hastinapura, because Dhritarashtra was blind by birth. He was disqualified. And Pandu had taken charge of ruling the entire world as the emperor, and Pandu died. And Yudhishthira should have ascended the throne, but if Dhritarashtra is not dead, would that mean he shall not be a successor? Since Yudhishthira was not an adult, a major—he was not quite eighteen years old—therefore, after Pandu died, as long as Yudhishthira would yield to the throne, a caretaker king was needed. And that caretaker king Bhishma refused because Bhishma had taken a vow not to sit on the throne. He had given a promise to his father. Therefore Dhritarashtra was the caretaker king and Bhishma and Vidura were advising.

### Dhritarashtra's unfairness, Pandavas' exile, House of Shellac, Vidura's warning
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Hw1wtbon5j0?t=350
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Ultimately a colossal clique was fabricated to deprive the five fatherless brothers of the rightful claim of the kingdom of Hastinapura."
**Summary:** This segment details Dhritarashtra's unfair treatment of the Pandavas, the conspiracy to deprive them of their kingdom, and the attempt to kill them in the house of shellac, highlighting Vidura's role in warning Yudhishthira.

They were advisors to Dhritarashtra and the entire royal household. But Dhritarashtra was not fair in his dealings, especially with the Pandavas. So Srila Prabhupada explained, "Ultimately a colossal clique was fabricated to deprive the five fatherless brothers of the rightful claim of the kingdom of Hastinapura." There was a great intrigue common in imperial palaces and the five brothers were exiled to wilderness. This is explained by Prabhupada in another place. What was this? This was a colossal clique that because these Pandavas were great devotees of Krishna and Dhritarashtra and Duryodhana were very materialistic. Naturally, Pandavas were put into many dangerous conditions. That is the policy of Dhritarashtra. How to kill the sons of Pandu? He wanted to kill the five sons of Pandu and usurp the kingdom for his own sons. He could not ascend the throne. So he felt that at least my sons should become the emperors. So he wanted to kill the five sons of Pandu just so that his son can become the emperor. So this was the policy from the very beginning. But the Pandavas, they were very obedient to Dhritarashtra because Dhritarashtra was their guardian, their uncle, elderly uncle, who had taken charge of protecting the five Pandavas and their mother Kunti in the absence of Pandu. So what did Dhritarashtra do? He constructed a house of shellac. Shellac means as soon as you touch one matchstick, immediately the whole palace will be on fire. So he asked his nephews and sisters-in-law Kunti that for some time you go. I constructed a very nice palace for you. You go and live there. Why you have to share this palace? So Vidura, he was very alert. He knew that Dhritarashtra and Duryodhana were plotting to kill the Pandavas. So Vidura informed Yudhishthira very secretly that Dhritarashtra wants to burn you to ashes when you go to that house. Be careful. And Duryodhana could understand that Vidura had already informed. Therefore Duryodhana was very anxious. He was very angry against Vidura. And these are all, this is the politics that was going on in the palace of Hastinapura during the time of the Pandavas and Kauravas.

So although Yudhishthira knew that my uncle is sending me to this house to set it on fire, still he was very obedient. So he agreed to go. He didn't want to disobey the superior because Yudhishthira was always morally upright. So they dug a subway into that house and they escaped. They dug a subway within that house, a tunnel, and then they escaped. So this is the way they escaped that danger to their life. The five Pandavas along with Kunti. Then another time Bhima was fed a poisoned cake. And again it's described in detail in the Mahabharata. Bhima was also saved. Then they had to meet one man-eater, rakshasa demon, Hidimba. So Bhima fought with him and killed him. And then in the assembly of ruffians, asatsabhaya, they attempted to disrobe Draupadi. But Draupadi took shelter of Krishna and she was protected. Then that is also described in detail in the Mahabharata. And then in a gambling match, which was completely rigged, the Pandavas were totally cheated. And when they lost the match, the terms were that whoever loses has to go and stay in the forest in exile for 13 years, out of which the last year, 13th year, they have to live incognito. They have to hide themselves. So in this way, the Pandavas, they were cheated and their life was in danger. Even when they were living in exile, Duryodhana attempted to attack the Pandavas and kill them. But the Pandavas fought back. And therefore the description is that they could not ultimately kill the Pandavas, though they tried. And in the battle of Kurukshetra, because Krishna was on the side of the Pandavas, the Pandavas could not be defeated by the Kauravas, even though the Kauravas were very powerful.

Therefore, after Bhishma's passing away, which they witnessed, how perfectly Bhishma quit his body, that was a lesson for everyone, even all the great sages, because even though the great sages know philosophically, in terms of knowledge, they have knowledge how to quit the body, but in reality, when one has to put that knowledge into practice, that is a different thing altogether. Application of the knowledge, that is called realization.

This is the perfection of life, that one is able to constantly think of Krishna, or one is able to constantly remember Krishna, one is able to constantly chant the holy name of the Supreme Lord Krishna. That way they can remain Krishna conscious. Whenever death comes, they are ready to quit the body. That is the practice actually which Krishna himself recommends in the Bhagavad Gita: tasmat sarveshu kaaleshu maa manu smara yudhya ca. So in the Bhagavatam this is described: sadhavo hrudayam mahyam sadhunam hrudayam tu aham maranya tena jananti naaham tebhyo managapi. This means the pure devotee is always within the core of my heart. This is a statement spoken by Lord Vishnu to Durvasamuni. So Vishnu is telling, Supreme Lord Vishnu is telling, the pure devotee is always within the core of my heart, and I am always in the heart of my pure devotee. See, it is reciprocal. Vishnu or Krishna carries always the memory of the pure devotee within his heart, and a pure devotee always carries Vishnu or Krishna within his heart, always, always. The sages who were assembled there, they participated in that funeral rituals, funeral ceremony of Bhishma Deva, great personality, and after that, before leaving for their own hermitages, they glorified Krishna, and how did they glorify Krishna? By reciting the Vedic hymns. The present trouble, if we are suffering now, is due to the fructifying of seedling sins. There is Papa Bija within our heart, everybody's heart. Everyone who has taken birth in this material world by force of karma has got in their heart what is called as Papa Bija, seedling sins. But even those seedling sins also gradually fade away by execution of pure devotional service. Anybody suffering is due to their own sinful activities performed in the past. And those sinful activities which they performed in the past resulted in Papa Bija being put in their heart. And that Papa Bija will gradually develop into Papa Phala. And that Papa Phala is what we experience as suffering. Different kinds of suffering depending on different kinds of Papa Phala. So, but somebody who performs pure devotional service... All the Papa Bijas are completely destroyed before they can fructify.

The five knowledge, the five knowledge acquiring senses, Gyanendriya: the eyes, the ears, the nose, the tongue and the sense of touch. And finally, there is the total stock of the unmanifested material energy, avyakta. Avyakta is the total stock of the material energy from which these elements are differentiated at the beginning of creation.

**Speaker:** HH Stoka Krishna Swami

### inconceivable energies of the Lord, devotee's perspective, karma, illusory energy (Maya)
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xsLpu-f0ZTY?t=51
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The material energy is always provoking doubts about the supreme authority of the Lord."
**Summary:** This segment discusses the inconceivable nature of the Lord's energies, the role of Maya, and how a devotee should not blame others or the Lord for difficulties, understanding the chain of cause and effect and the influence of past karma.

In this session we will be discussing from the 23rd verse of the 17th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. अथवा देवामायाया नूनम गतिर अगोचरा चेतसो वचसस्चापी भूतानाम इति निष्चयहा The meaning of this 23rd verse is, "Thus it is concluded that the Lord's energies are inconceivable. No one can estimate them by mental speculation or by word." Now, this is a conclusion that is drawn by Pariksit Maharaj. The Lord's energies are inconceivable. The Lord's energies are working, especially in this material world and even in the spiritual world. But in the spiritual world it is the spiritual energy, internal potency which is working. And in the material world it is the external potency, the material energy which is working. Both of them are controlled, owned, directed by the Supreme Lord only. Krishna only is the owner, controller, director, master of all the energies. So, by mental speculation we cannot figure out how the Lord's energies are working. How the Lord's energies are working in different circumstances. We cannot make calculation, material calculation. That's impossible. So, in the Purport, Srila Prabhupada explains, "A question may be raised as to why a devotee should refrain from identifying an actor, although he knows definitely that the Lord is the ultimate doer of everything. A devotee does not blame anyone for any difficulty or danger." A doer knows the problem he may be facing. Why? Even though he knows that the Lord is the ultimate doer. But that doesn't mean he blames the Lord. Neither he blames the person who is the immediate cause. And therefore he also blames the Lord as the person who is the immediate cause, because there are a chain of causes and defects. And every effect there is a cause, and every cause there is a particular justification why, why that cause is actually being sanctioned by the law. Knowing the ultimate doer, one should not pose himself as ignorant of the actual performer. So, it's not that because anyway, ultimately, every person suffers because of his or her own past bad karma, I or anyone else doesn't have the license to inflict harm on others, that is not a license. It's just like sometimes people say, anyway, the animal is going to die. So, if I kill it for some food, what is wrong there? It's going to die. Animal is not the body. After all, I can only kill the body. I cannot kill the soul. Animal or the living entity is the soul. So, this reasoning or argument is not correct, is invalid. The perpetrator of a sinful activity is definitely responsible for this sinful action, and is going to be punished by God's laws, the laws of karma. Of this, there is no doubt at all. Yet, when the sinful action is sanctioned by the Lord, then there is a higher cause. So, it is said here, to answer this doubt, the reply is that the Lord is also not directly responsible for everything, is done by his deputed maya shakti or material energy. In the material world, maya shakti, material energy is working. In every case, every material action, material energy is working. The material energy is always provoking doubts about the supreme authority of the Lord, because we directly don't see the Lord's hand in every action in this material world. But still, the fact is, the Lord is always in the background, and he only is directing the material energy. The personality of religion knew perfectly well that nothing can take place without the sanction of the Supreme Lord, and still he was put into doubts by the deluding energy. And thus, he refrained from mentioning the supreme cause. This doubtfulness was due to the contamination of both Kali and the material energy. When dharma does not complain against the Kali Purusha, so, does it mean that, oh, Kali Purusha is not directly responsible, so, he is not a culprit. So, Pariksit need not punish him? No, that is incorrect. At the same time, the Lord is sanctioning, only then Kali Purusha can do some harm. So, Lord is responsible? No, the Lord is not responsible. The whole atmosphere of the age of Kali is magnified by the deluding energy, and the proportion of measurement is inexplicable. The material world always, Maya's actions are definitely the direct cause of any suffering that anybody may undergo. But then, our own past sinful actions are also responsible. We are responsible. So, how does this illusory energy work? Is the question that may be raised. So, it is not easy to understand the working of the illusory energy in each and every case.

### illusory energy (Maya), Markandeya Rishi, prayer, spiritual practice
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xsLpu-f0ZTY?t=486
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "I wish to see your illusory potency, by whose influence the entire world, together with its ruling demigods, consider reality to be materially variegated."
**Summary:** This segment introduces the story of Markandeya Rishi, who prayed to see the Lord's illusory energy in action, highlighting his detachment from material benefits and his desire to understand Maya's influence.

So, I want to briefly narrate a particular description in the 12th Kant of the Bhagavatam. Tiruvannamalai. There was one Markandeya Rishi. He once prayed to the Supreme Lord, "I want to see your illusory energy in action." Because he is himself a great tapasvi, he is situated above the influence of the illusory energy. But he is seeing the illusory energy working. So many people are under the clutches of maya and they are engaged in either material enjoyment or they sometimes suffer and they are in ignorance and they are perpetually in the cycle of birth and death. They have no clue how to get out because of ignorance. So how is this material energy working? I wanted to see. This is what Markandeya wanted to actually ask the Lord. So once when Markandeya Rishi was sitting in his ashram performing his spiritual practice, the Supreme Lord appeared in his incarnation as Naranarayanarishi, the twin sages. And Markandeya Rishi received Naranarayanarishi very nicely. And after they had been offered all kinds of good reception, according to Vedic culture, then when they were seated, Markandeya Rishi offered nice prayers to them and the Lord, being satisfied, asked him, "You can ask any benediction that you desire." So he said, "I am not interested in any material benefit," knowing very well that they are useless from a spiritual perspective. "But I want to... I wish to see your illusory potency, by whose influence the entire world, together with its ruling demigods, consider reality to be materially variegated." They mistake this material energy itself to be the absolute truth. No. Material energy is not the absolute truth. Krishna is the absolute truth. Krishna is in the background. Material energy is completely controlled, directed, owned by Krishna. Now, Markandeya's prayer to the Supreme Lord was accepted. And Supreme Lord said, "So be it." And they departed for their ashram in Badrikashram. Thinking always of his desire to see the Lord's illusory energy, Markandeya Rishi remained in his ashram, meditating constantly upon the Lord within fire, the sun, the moon, the water, the earth, the air, lightning, his own heart, and worshipping him with paraphernalia conceived in his mind.
