### illusory energy (Maya), Markandeya Rishi, deluge, fear, divine test
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xsLpu-f0ZTY?t=691
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Even as Markandeya looked on, the rain pouring down from the clouds filled the ocean more and more and more until the great sea covered up the earth's islands, mountains, continents."
**Summary:** This segment describes the devastating flood created by the Lord's illusory energy, showing Markandeya Rishi's experience of fear, hunger, and disorientation as he wandered through the deluge.

One day, while Markandeya Rishi was performing his evening worship, suddenly a great wind arose. That wind created a terrible sound and brought in its wake fearsome clouds that were accompanied by lightning and roaring thunder. And the clouds poured down torrents of rain. Then on all sides, Markandeya Rishi saw the four great oceans swelling up. And there was gusty wind. And these oceans were filled with sea monsters. And they were very, very fearsome. There were whirlpools. The sage saw all the inhabitants of the universe, including himself, tormented by the harsh winds. The bolts of lightning, the great waves rising beyond the sky, the whole earth became flooded, and he became perplexed and fearful. Remember, Markandeya Rishi had prayed to the Lord, "I want to see your illusory energy in action." And now, actually the Lord is showing him what is my illusory energy like. Even as Markandeya looked on, the rain pouring down from the clouds filled the ocean more and more and more until the great sea covered up the earth's islands, mountains, continents. Completely the earth became submerged. Not only that water flooded the earth, but it also flooded the outer space, heaven, celestial region. Entire expanse of the universe was flooded in all directions. And it appeared like only Markandeya Rishi remained alive in that flood, great deluge, devastating flood. His matted hair scattered. The great sage wandered about alone in the water as if dumb and blind. He didn't know where to go, what to do. He's alive. He's somehow floating. And he doesn't know where to go and what to do. He was also tormented by hunger and thirst. He was attacked by monstrous makaras and timingala fish. Makaras means crocodiles. And very dangerous crocodiles which are huge. You can easily swallow up hundreds of Markandeya Rishis. And timingala fish. These fishes are very, very dangerous. They can devour an entire big blue sea whale. Huge. As big as ocean liners. That is attacked by a timingala. Timingala is very, very dangerous. So he saw timingala fishes. He saw monstrous crocodiles. And he was battered by the wind and waves. He moved aimlessly in the infinite darkness into which he had fallen. Suddenly, he saw millions of years pass like that, wandering in that huge flood. His mind bewildered by the illusory energy of the Supreme Personality of Godhead Lord Vishnu.

### illusory energy (Maya), Markandeya Rishi, vata patra shayi, divine revelation, liberation
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xsLpu-f0ZTY?t=921
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Suddenly the child inhaled everything and Markandeya found himself within the body of the child."
**Summary:** This segment narrates Markandeya Rishi's encounter with the infant Vata Patra Shayi, his experience of being inside the Lord's body, and his eventual return to his ashram, illustrating the power and mystery of the Lord's illusory energy.

Once while wandering in the water, millions of years have passed, this Brahmana Markandeya Rishi discovered a small island. Now on this small island was a young banyan tree. And it was having... It was unaffected by that flood, by the hurricane wind, by the violent storm, everything. This stood with nice fruits and nice blossoms of flowers. Now on a branch of that tree, he saw an infant boy, small boy, lying within a leaf. The child's effulgence was swallowing up the darkness. The infant's dark blue complexion was the color of a flawless emerald. His lotus face shone with a wealth of beauty. His throat bore marks like the lines of a conch shell. This is the Supreme Lord appearing in that form, Vata Patra Shai. He is lying on a banyan leaf, and he was sucking the toe within his mouth. So Markandeya when he saw the child, all his fatigue vanished. And just looking at the child, he felt great joy within his heart. Now who is this infant? He tried to go near the infant. And suddenly the child inhaled everything, and Markandeya found himself within the body of the child. And inside he found the universe was as it was before the dissolution. He was astonished. He saw the heavens. He saw the earth. He saw the stars. He saw the mountains. He saw everything. And he saw before him his own Badra river, his own hermitage. Now as he was kind of thinking, oh now the illusion is over, suddenly the infant exhaled and expelled the sage out of its abdomen. And he was back into the ocean of dissolution. At that moment that child, when he came out, became again visible, invisible, became invisible. And suddenly everything vanished. The whole storm and the oceans which were flooded, everything vanished. And Markandeya Rishi found himself in his ashram, as he was seated. So this was the display of the illusory energy by the Lord. I'll stop here. Thank you very much.

**Summary:** The speaker introduces the 24th verse of the 17th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, explaining how Dharma, represented as a bull, stood on four legs (austerity, cleanliness, mercy, and truthfulness) in Satya Yuga, but gradually lost three legs as the ages progressed.

In this session we will be discussing from the 24th verse of the 17th chapter of the 1st canto of Shri Madbhagavatam Tapashaucham Dayasatyam Iti Pada Kriteyam Kriyate Krutah Adharmam Shais Trayobhagna Smaya Sanga Madais Tava. The meaning of this verse is: In the age of Satya, truthfulness, your four legs were established by the four principles of austerity, cleanliness, mercy and truthfulness. But it appears that three of your legs are broken due to rampant irreligion in the form of pride, lust for women and intoxication. So Parikshit Maharaj is speaking to the personality of religious principle dharma, the bull in the shape of the bow. That dharma in the beginning of the cycle of four yugas in Satya yuga was established on four legs, four pillars of dharma, what are they? Austerity, cleanliness, mercy and truthfulness. Tapaha, Shaucham, Daya, Satyam. Tapa means austerity, Shaucham means cleanliness, Daya means mercy, Satyam means truthfulness.

Once Sivananda Sena offered food to Lord Chaitanya that had been cooked with excessive ghee, and the next day, Lord Chaitanya became sick and went to Murari Gupta for treatment. Lord Chaitanya accepted some water from the water pot of Murari Gupta, and thus, he was cured. The natural remedy for indigestion is to drink a little water, and since Murari Gupta was a physician, he gave the Lord some drinking water and cured him. Once Lord Chaitanya Mahaprabhu glorified Murari Gupta for his unflinching devotion and loyalty to Lord Rama Chandra because Murari Gupta was a great devotee of Lord Rama. In Mahaprakasha form, Lord Chaitanya appeared before Murari Gupta as Lord Ramachandra. Just to test Murari's faith, he repeatedly encouraged Murari Gupta to shift his worship from Lord Rama to Lord Krishna, describing the unparalleled sweetness, supremacy, and all-attractive nature of Shri Krishna, who is the origin of all incarnations and the reservoir of all transcendental qualities and pleasure. Although Murari heard these divine glories of Krishna from the Lord himself, his heart remained steadfastly fixed on his eternal master Lord Ramachandra. Murari, being utterly devoted, could not imagine giving up the service of Lord Rama's lotus feet. That night he was deeply troubled, weeping continuously and praying that death might take him before he was forced to abandon his worship of Lord Ramachandra. He spent the entire night awake, overwhelmed by distress. The next morning Murari approached Lord Chaitanya, fell at his feet, and humbly confessed that though he desired to please the Lord, he could not forsake Lord Ramachandra, for he had sold his head and heart to Lord Rama's service. Torn between obedience to Chaitanya's command and loyalty to Lord Ramachandra, Murari begged for death as his only release. Hearing this pure devotion, Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu became overjoyed. Embracing Murari Gupta, Lord Chaitanya praised his unwavering faith, declaring that such steadfast devotion is a true hallmark of a servant. The Lord revealed that his repeated persuasion was merely a test to demonstrate Murari's deep, unbreakable attachment to Lord Ramachandra.

### childhood, devotion, detachment
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Ugj5n_4y1b8?t=47
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Even as a child, Narottama demonstrated profound devotion during his Annaprashana ceremony, he refused to eat until the food was first offered to Lord Krishna, thus teaching the sanctity of Prasadam."
**Summary:** Description of Narottam Das Thakur's birth, childhood, early signs of devotion, and growing detachment from material life.

in the village of Kheturi in present-day Bangladesh around the mid-16th century. Narottama appeared on the full moon day of Magha as the son of King Krishnananda Datta and Queen Narayani Devi. His birth was marked by auspicious omens, and the entire kingdom rejoiced with his father distributing generous charity to the local brahmanas. Even as a child, Narottama demonstrated profound devotion during his Annaprashana ceremony, which is the first grain feeding ceremony for the infant child. He refused to eat until the food was first offered to Lord Krishna, thus teaching the sanctity of Prasadam. An astrologer observing his divine features declared that the child would become the greatest among men and thus should be named Narottama. Gifted with an extraordinary memory, Narottama was a Shruti Dharam, able to retain everything he heard. He mastered Sanskrit, grammar and the Vedas with ease, but his heart was fixed on serving Krishna. Remaining a lifelong Brahmachari, he was indifferent to the comforts of royal life. Concerned by his growing detachment, his parents placed guards to keep watch over him. But Narottama's only happiness lay in hearing the divine pastimes of Lord Chaitanya and Lord Nityananda, narrated to him daily.

daily by Shri Krishnadas Kaviraj Goswami. Immersed in remembrance of the Lord, he once had a dream in which Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu instructed him to travel to Vrindavan. When his father was away, Narottama escaped from home to fulfill the Lord's instruction. As he journeyed toward Vrindavan, his saintly nature attracted everyone's affection and people offered him food and shelter along the way. Upon reaching Vrindavan, he met Srila Jeeva Goswami and Srinivasa Acharya. Their meeting was filled with spiritual joy and affection and Narottama and Srinivasa soon became inseparable friends united in their love for the Lord. Srila Jeeva Goswami introduced Narottama to Shri Loknath Goswami. Narottama humbly fell at his feet and Loknath Goswami moved by his sincerity blessed him and later agreed to initiate him. Srila Jeeva Goswami also introduced Narottama to Shri Gopalabhatta Goswami and Shri Bhuggadbhag Goswami who received him affectionately. Narottama visited the holy temples of Rathadamoda and Madan Mohan and upon seeing the samadhis of Rupa and Sanatana Goswamis, he wept uncontrollably in love and devotion. Later with Srinivasa Acharya, he visited Radhakunda and Shamakunda and received the blessings of Sri Raghunath Das Goswami who was deeply touched by his devotion. Under the care of Jeeva Goswami, Narottama studied deeply the scriptures of Bhakti and soon became renowned for his humility, scholarship and realization. Srila Lokarnath Goswami, seeing Narottama's pure-hearted service finally initiated him into the chanting of the Maha Mantra. His exceptional understanding of devotional literature impressed all the Vaishnavas of Vrindavan and Sri Jeeva Goswami bestowed upon him the title Sri Thakur Mahasaya.

festival at his birthplace, the first large-scale God Purnima celebration which commemorates Lord Chaitanya's appearance. This event united Lord Chaitanya's followers from many regions and established the foundation for his worship across Bengal. Although born into a Kayastha community, traditionally considered of lower caste, Narottama became the spiritual master of thousands including many learned brahmanas such as Ganga Narayan Chakravarthi and Ramachandra Kaviraj. These exalted disciples humbly served him, acknowledging his transcendental position. Despite criticism from caste conscious brahmanas, Narottama remained compassionate, embracing everyone equally and demonstrating that spiritual qualification is measured by devotion not by birth. In his later life, Narottama became a spiritual master of the old caste. This is the reason why he became a spiritual master of the new caste. After his death, Narottama experienced deep separation from the Lord and his associates. Having witnessed the departure of the six Goswamis, Srinivas Acharya and Ramachandra Kaviraj, he poured his heart out in the famous song Jai Anilo Prema Dhana, expressing grief over the loss of the great devotees who brought divine love to the world. His disappearance was miraculous. Aware that bathe him by pouring Ganga water over his body. As they did this, his body turned white like milk and gradually melted into the sacred Ganges. Heartbroken but obedient, his disciples collected the mixture of milk, tears, and Ganga water and enshrined it at Kheturi, where a beautiful Samadhi was built, known as Dut Samadhi, the Samadhi of Milk. Srila Narottam Das Thakur remains a radiant example of pure devotion, humility, and compassion. His life and songs reveal the heart of Prema Bhakti, unconditional love for Krishna, and his teachings transcend all material distinctions. Srila Prabhupada revered his bhajans as spiritual scripture and they continue to inspire generations

### Kumaras, Vaikuntha, Doorkeepers, Srila Prabhupada
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/EKiUi9ClDW0?t=0
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Thus ends the Bhaktivedanta Purpa."
**Summary:** The speaker reads the translation and purport of S.B. 3.15.30, focusing on the Kumaras' appearance, their age, and the doorkeepers' actions.

Translation: The four boy sages, who had nothing to cover their bodies but the atmosphere, looked only five years old, even though they were the oldest of all living creatures and had realized the truth of the self. But when the porters, who happened to possess a disposition quite unpalatable to the Lord, saw the sages, they blocked their way with their staffs, despising their glories, although the sages did not deserve such treatment at their hands. Purport by Srila Prabhupada: The four sages were the first born sons of Brahma; therefore, all other living entities, including Lord Shiva, are born later and are therefore younger than the four Kumaras. Although they looked like five-year-old boys and traveled naked, the Kumaras were older than all other living creatures and had realized the truth of the self, such that they could not remain negligible and thus became known as the king of all the world. However, the sages were not to be forbidden to enter the kingdom of Vaikuntha, but by chance the doorman objected to their entrance. This is not fitting. The Lord is always anxious to serve sages like the Kumaras, but in spite of knowing this fact, the doorman astonishingly and outrageously prohibited them from entering. Thus ends the Bhaktivedanta Purport.

So here the question is, Krishna and Brahma didn't come to know. They tend to have no idea. So Brahma also came to know when something happened. What happened? When they were cow herding, the older cows came running down to the calves. Even though it's very unusual, they never do so and they started, you know, licking the body of the calf. And cowherd men who were in charge of those cows, they became very angry at the cows. But when they came down, they are suddenly embracing the cowherd boys. So Balarama saw unusual affection between the cowherd boys and the cowherd men and between the cows and the cows. And then he asked Krishna, what is going on? What is happening? So your question is, how is that Balarama doesn't know? This is called Leela. For the Leela to take place, it is arranged that Balarama doesn't know that Krishna has expanded and Brahma has stolen. Balarama doesn't know, for the sake of the Leela. Like Kaliya, Dhaman Leela, when everybody became anxious, where is Krishna? Some ill omens. And then they all went and Balarama went with them. Then they are all trying to do something to save Krishna. He is in the clutches of Kaliya. Balarama is laughing. He knows nothing will happen to Krishna. Therefore, he is the greatest well-wisher. He is the best well-wishing friend of everyone, and the Kumaras wanted to see him. In this verse, it is figuratively stated that the younger brother of desire suddenly appeared in person when the sages were forbidden to see their most beloved personality of Godhead. The younger brother of desire is anger.

### anger, liberation, Krishna consciousness, sense gratification
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/KHe8E-ZPO-4?t=231
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The difference between the anger of an ordinary person and that of a liberated person is that an ordinary person becomes angry because his sense desires are not being fulfilled, whereas a liberated person like the Kumaras becomes angry when restricted in the discharge of duties for serving the Supreme Personality of Godhead."
**Summary:** The speaker differentiates between anger in the conditioned and liberated states, emphasizing that liberated individuals become angry when service to Krishna is obstructed, not for personal gratification.

If once desire is not fulfilled, the younger brother anger follows. Here we can mark that even great saintly persons like the Kumaras were also angry, but they were not angry for their personal interests. They were angry because they were forbidden to enter the palace to see the personality of Godhead. Therefore, the theory that in the perfectional stage one should not have anger is not supported in this verse. Anger will continue even in the liberated stage. These four mendicant brothers, the Kumaras, were considered liberated persons, but still they were angry because they were restricted in their service to the Lord. The difference between the anger of an ordinary person and that of a liberated person is that an ordinary person becomes angry because his sense desires are not being fulfilled, whereas a liberated person like the Kumaras becomes angry when restricted in the discharge of duties for serving the Supreme Personality of Godhead. In the previous verse, it has been clearly mentioned that the Kumaras were liberated persons. Vidhita Atma Tattva means one who understands the truth of self-realization. One who does not understand the truth of self-realization is called ignorant. But one who understands the self, the super-self, their interrelation and activities in self-realization is called Vidhita Atma Tattva. Although the Kumaras were already liberated persons, they nevertheless became angry. This point is very important. Becoming liberated does not necessitate losing one's sensual activities. Sense activities continue even in the liberated stage. The difference is, however, that sense activities in liberation are accepted only in connection with Krishna Consciousness, whereas sense activities in the conditioned stage are enacted for personal sense gratification.

The daughter of a Kshatriya can see the valor of her would-be husband. A Kshatriya princess, she wants demonstration before she marries another Kshatriya king. Kshatriya means he should have the courage to fight to the extent that if required he is willing to give up his life, but he will not give up the fight. Yuddhecha api apalayanam. This is described in the Bhagavad Gita by Krishna in the 18th chapter, in the 43rd verse, describing the qualities of a Kshatriya. A Kshatriya is courageous in battle. The 29th verse: Tam Jighamsum Abhipretya Vihaya Drupalanchanam Tadpada Moolam Shirasa Samagatbhaya Vikvalaha. The meaning of this verse is, when the personality of Kali understood that the king was willing to kill him, he at once abandoned the dress and, under pressure of fear, completely surrendered to him, bowing his head. So, what is Kali Purusha's reaction to Parikshit Maharaj being ready to kill Kali Purusha because Kali Purusha was harming an innocent cow and a bull? So, Kali Purusha understood that he cannot face the king, the emperor Parikshit, and he at once gave up the dress of a king. He is actually not a king, he is dressed as a king for external show, and he completely surrendered to Parikshit Maharaj.
